By letter dated October 10, 2014, Ms. Tamela Wells, the Grievant was notified that she was being terminated from her employment with Dart Container Corporation's Solo Cup Operating Facility in Augusta, Georgia.
According to the record, on October 10, 2014, the Grievant, Ms. Wells was called by Ms. Jennifer Davis, Human Resources Manager, Dart Container Corporation, Solo Cup Operation Facility, and participated in a three-way conversation with Ms. Davis and her Regional Business Manager, Mr. Howard Quales, during which Ms. Davis and Ms. Quales informed Ms. Wells that she was being terminated. The letter dated October 10, 2014, was actually received by the Grievant on or about October 15, 2014, and simply transmitted a completed/signed/dated State of Georgia Department of Labor Separation Notice, providing that the reason for separation was “unable to return from leave. Under Georgia's Employment Security Law, OCGA §34-8-199 and rules pursuant thereto, a Separation Notice, form DOL-800, must be completed for each worker who leaves a company's/firm's employment, regardless of the reason for the separation. In accordance with the provisions of Article 10 of the parties' CBA, on October 16, 2014, Ms. Wells filed a formal grievance contending that the separation was improper, unfair, unjust; and the Company did not have just cause to terminate her under the CBA With the grievance unresolved, in accordance with the provision of Article 11 of the CBA, the Union appealed the action to arbitration.

By letter dated January 27, 2015, the U. S. Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service (FMCS) informed the undersigned Arbitrator that the parties had jointly selected him and FMCS was appointing him to hear and decide the above cited matter. Following telephonic and email communications with the parties, by letter dated February 5, 2015, the Arbitrator informed the parties that he accepted their appointment, outlined the basic procedures to be followed, confirmed and explained his per diem rates and charge policies, and offered three periods of time that he was available to hear the matter - April 22-23, June 2-3, and June 9-10,2015.

Following additional communications with the parties, by letter dated February 18, 2015, the Arbitrator scheduled a hearing in the above cited matter to be held Wednesday and Thursday, April 22 and 23,2015, in a conference room of the Hilton Garden Inn, 1085 Stevens Creek Road Augusta, Georgia, 30907; with an administrative conference with the parties to convene at 8:30AM, April 22nd and the hearing to commence immediately at the conclusion of the administrative conference. The hearing scheduling letter also requested that the parties provide the Arbitrator with a copy of the parties' collective bargaining agreement together with any amendments and/or memorandums of understanding, as well as, the grievance file. The parties were also provided an opportunity to file pre-hearing briefs, and informed when they should exchange witness lists.
The hearing scheduling letter was amended by letter dated March 13, 2015, providing the address were the hearing was to be held.

At 8:30AM, Wednesday, April 22, 2015, the Arbitrator held an administrative conference with the parties to discuss, among other things, the purpose of the hearing; hearing procedures, including attendance and the handling of witnesses; the recording of the hearing
While Article 11, Section 2 of the parties' CBA provides how costs associated with recorders/transcription services will be handled, neither of the parties requested and/or provided for official recording/transcription services. As explained and discussed during the administrative conference, the Arbitrator recorded the hearing; and, per the discussion and parties' request provided the parties' a copy of his audio files. On this point the parties stipulated that the CBA provided is the current and applicable CBA and that the CBA presented was properly extended and continues in effect Accordingly, the parties further stipulated that there were no arbitrability issues or questions that needed to be addressed.
Article 10 — Complaints, provides as follows:
Section 1 - Both parties to this agreement shall have the right to present grievances as provided In this Article. It is mutually agreed that all grievances, defined as a dispute or complaint arising during the term of this Agreement over the interpretation or application of its contents, shall be settled in accordance with the provisions herein provided.
Every effort shall be made to adjust grievances in an amicable manner between the Company and the Union. In the event that any grievance cannot be settled in this manner, the question may be submitted by either for arbitration as provided in Article 11.
Section 2 - Should any grievance arise over the interpretation or application of the contents of this Agreement there shall be an earnest effort on the part of the parties to settle such promptly and no grievance will be considered or discussed which is presented later than five (5) working days after the occurrrence.
Step 1. If an employee has a grievance, he or his steward will reduce the grievance to writting and present it to the aggrieved employee's immediate supervisor within five (5) working days after the occurrence. The supervisor will give his answer within four working days after receiving the written grievance.
Step 2. If no settlement is reached at Step 1, the matter may be referred to the chief steward and presented to the department manager within five (5) days from the Step 1 answer. The department manager will give an answer within five (5) days.
Step 3. If no settlement is reached at Step 2, the matter may be referred to the representative of the union, the Human Resources Manager or the Plant Manager within fourteen (14) days from the Step 2 answer. The Human Resources Manager will provide the Company's answer within seven (7) days.
Section 3 - Grievances involving discharges, if not settled within five (5) days, shall at the request of either party be referred directly to Step 3 of the grievance procedure.
Section 4 - If a party fails to abide by the above time limits, the matter will be settled in favor of the other party. Grievances being settled by monetary adjustments shall be settled within ten (10) working days and shall be paid within 21 calendar days of the settlement. Time limits may be extended by mutual agreement in writing and the Union will not unreasonably withhold agreement. The grievant may be present at each step of the grievance procedure.
Article 11 — Arbitration, provides as follows:
Section 1 - If a grievance is not settled pursuant to the procedure set forth in Article 10, it will be at the request of either the Union or the Company submitted to arbitration and the decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding on both parties. In such event, the party desiring arbitration shall notify the other party in writing within ten (10) days after the termination of the proceedings set forth in Article 10, which writing shall set forth the matter to be arbitrated. The parties may mutually agree upon an arbitrator, but if they are unable to do so within five (5) days, either party shall request the Federal Mediation and Concidiation Service to provide a panel of arbitrators, all of whom shall be members of the National Academy of Arbitrators, and invoke its procedure for the selection of an arbitrator to conduct the arbitration in accordance With its Rules on Voluntary Labor Arbitration.
The arbitrator shall have no power to add to, subtract from or modify the terms of this Agreement and premiums for jobs or to set or change standards of production.
Section 2 - Each party shall bear the costs of preparation, representation, witnesses, etc., for their respective case; however, all fees and expenses of the arbitrator will be borne by the loser of said arbitration. Charges for stenographer's fees and expenses shall be borne by the party ordering such services.

After discussing streamlining measures, rules of evidence, post-hearing briefs, and when the parties could expect the written decision and award; and determining that no other matters needed to be covered, the administrative conference was adjourned at 8:50AM, and the hearing on the matter convened at 9:10AM, Wednesday, April 22,2015.

As explained at the administrative conference, three exhibit lists were being maintained - (1) the Arbitrator/Joint Exhibit list which would record all documentary evidence Identified as joint exhibits and all documentary evidence requested by the Arbitrator; (2) the Company/Employer List recording all documentary evidence offered by and accepted from the Company; and (3) the Union/Grievant List recording all documentary evidence offered by and accepted from the Grievant., and entered into the record the initial three (3) exhibits identified as Arbitrator/Joint exhibits; explained ail previous communications with the parties, including any dealings with the parties during his thirty-plus years Federal service; and, asked the parties if they had any concerns or issues regarding his ability to conduct a fair and impartial hearing on the matter before him - To which both parties answered they had no objection.

Following opening statements the hearing then proceeded in an orderly manner. All witnesses testified under oath as administered by the Arbitrator.

The Company's advocate and Counsel, as well as, the Grievant's advocate and Counsel, fully and fairly represented their respective party. While the hearing record was open, and/or subsequently as requested by the Arbitrator, a total of twelve (12) Arbitrator/Joint exhibits were offered and accepted into the record; eight (8) Company/Employer exhibits offered and accepted; and eighteen (18) Union/Grievant exhibits offered and accepted. Following receipt of the post-hearing briefs and rebuttal briefs, the hearing record was closed at 8:00AM EDT, Tuesday, July 7,2015.
As discussed at the administrative conference and confirmed at the close of the hearing, Article 11, of the parties' CBA provides no guidance as to when the parties should expect the Arbitrator to render his decision/award. Accordingly, the undersigned Arbitrator acknowledges the position of the parties; that the matter is properly before him in accordance with the appropriate provisions of law, regulations, and the parties CBA
While the parties' collective bargaining agreement has been noted and several provisions already cited, the Arbitrator further notes that while all provisions of the parties' agreement may be considered for applicability to. and guidance on, the current matter, the following specific provisions are deemed paramount — Article 2-Recognition; Article 5-Management Rights; Article 8-Seniority; Article 9-Job Posting; Article 10-Complaints; Article 11-Arbitration; Article 12-Hours of Work; Article 21-Family and Medical Leave; Article 27-Fair Employment Practices and Equal Opportunities; Article 36-Duration of Agreement; and Appendix showing Job classifications by department/operation.; that he is solely responsible to hear and determine the issues; and to render a written decision and award, in accordance with FMCS policies, and State and Federal law.

To this end, the undersigned has thoroughly reviewed the evidence presented in pre-hearing submissions, through testimony
With regard to the documentary evidence presented, and particularly the witness testimony presented at hearing, the Arbitrator has sought to impress upon the parties that a primary goal of his management of the hearing is to provide the parties the maximum opportunity to provide the evidence it feels necessary to adequately present its case. As to witnesses the Arbitrator is particularly cognizant of the need to assess the veracity of witnesses by paying particular attention to the demeanor of the witness, the character of the testimony, and any self-interest of the witness. and exhibits offered/accepted at hearing; and, through post-hearing briefs, rebuttals, and clarifying information submitted by the parties. The Arbitrator does not feel compelled to address all of the numerous arguments and issues raised by the advocates. However, please do not interpret this to mean that the Arbitrator has not read and reread the parties' briefs, rebuttals, citations includes in the some 1,158 pages of documents submitted as evidence; as well as, thoroughly listened/reviewed the several hours of audio files of the hearing; and carefully considered all arguments by the advocates. Rather, the Arbitrator elects to address only those elements that have a significant impact on his decision-making process. The Arbitrator, as a general rule, will not comment on matters that he believes are irrelevant superfluous, redundant, or rendered moot by his decision. The following decision and award will serve as the Arbitrator's final and binding decision regarding this matter.

The grievant, Ms. Tamela Wells, began her employment with the Solo Cup Company's
According to information on the Dart Container Corporation's website, Solo Cup Company, which manufactures disposable consumer products including beverage cups, disposable plates and bowls, was founded in 1936, with headquarters in Lake Forest Illinois, and by 2011 was a $1.6 billion global company with facilities in Europe and the Americas. On May 4, 2012, Dart Container Corporation acquired Solo Cup Company, including its Augusta, Georgia facility, and now employees an estimated 15,000 employees with more than forty-five production, distribution center, and office locations in eight countries. Augusta, Georgia facility on March 29, 1982, as a packer, then worked as a machine operator and production worker before becoming a forklift operator in 1990.
The parties' applicable/current CBA provides for and covers two groups of employees (Bargaining unit employees)…Group one includes the job classifications/categories sweeper-operator, utility, production worker, material handler and product handler working primarily in the Buildings and Grounds Department and General Production Department; Group two includes all other Job classifications/categories [Machine operator I, II, III, and IV; Plate Maker; Bagger Technician; Electro-Mechanical Technician; Maintenance Mechanic; Electrician; Senior Spare-Parts Attendant; Senior QC Technician; QC Technician; and Forklift Operator] working primarily in the Printing and Press, Foam Dinnerware, Trophy, Extrusion, Maintenance, Quality-Control, Warehouse and Material Handling Departments. Accordingly, the Grievant worked both group one and group two jobs. Her current position is a group two job. She remained in this job/classification until her separation on October 10, 2014. At the time of her separation, Ms. Wells had had approximately thirty-two years of service, had been a Union Steward for twenty-five years, and was one of the more senior employees.

After the acquisition of Solo Cup Company in May of 2012, by Dart Container Corporation, in 2013, management at the Augusta facility made the decision to transition from use of sit-down forklifts to stand-up forklifts. Management announced the transition to the Augusta workforce through a series of plant-wide meetings, and the new forklifts were delivered in February 2014. With the delivery of the new stand-up forklifts, the facility began a training and certification program
The record indicates that the Augusta facility contracted with an outside provider to train and certify each employee identified as required by their Job functions to operate a forklift. The training consisted of classroom (addressing theory, understanding of the machines components, inspections, etc.) and operational training (actual skills assessment (driving, making turns, clearances, etc.). Each individual was required to pass a written test as well as a driving/operational test. The Grievant, Ms. Wells participated in the training, passing the written test and operational skills component for certification on March 5, 2014. for all operators, and beginning in April 2014, the sit-down lifts were phased out and operators began using the new stand-up lifts full time.

In mid-March 2014, after completion of the training/certification program, the Grievant, Ms. Wells, began driving the new stand-up lift on a regular full time basis. Almost immediately after beginning full time operation of the new stand-up forklift, the Grievant began having issues of swollen ankles, back strain, tingling and numb feet; sufficient enough to cause Ms. Wells to discuss her problems with Company officials
The record is not clear as to whom in the Augusta facility the Grievant initially talked to regarding her medical problems. However, the evidence does show that Ms. Wells received a letter dated March 11, 2014 (Note: The copy of the correspondence offered/accepted by the Company as Employer exhibit E-5 was a single page letter dated/stamped mailed March 11, 2014, to Ms. Wells in response to her request for changes to her current position due to a medical condition. The letter noted that the request was accepted as a request for accommodation under the Americans with Disability Act; went on to explain what was needed to be covered and eligible for a reasonable accommodation under the Act; provided a Fact Sheet regarding the Disabitty Accommodation Process, as well as, a blank Request for Disability Accommodation (Dart form HR302a dated 6/13) which needed to be completed; requested the following documentation/information: (1) medical documentation of the impairment and how it affects a major life activity, (2) whether the condition is permanent or long term, and (3) which of the essential functions outlined in the attached job description are affected by the impairment, as well as any suggestions Ms. Well's health care provider may have for accommodations that would allow her to perform the essential duties; and informed her if she had any questions to contact the Human Resources Department. This communication presented as the initial official communication from the Company and reported as transmitting the identified documents to Ms. Wells, was unsigned. Nevertheless, Union exhibit U-10 (a copy of a letter from Dart LOA/ADA Specialist Michelle Jones to Ms. Wells dated April 30, 2014, (which was formally dated March 11.2014 but was corrected at hearing to have been produced/sent on/or about April 30, 2014) included a completed Request for Disability Accommodation (Dart HR302a) signed by Ms. Wells and dated March 21, 2014; showing that the Company had provided the blank forms to the Grievant prior to March 21.2014. and seek medical attention.
This initial doctor's visit was with Dr. Darrell Boutwell, a chiropractor Ms. Wells had been a patient of Dr. Boutweil for about ten years. Dr. Boutwell found the Grievant had chronic tower back and left saroillac paid due to a degenerative arthritic condition; and recommended that Ms. Wells refrain from long periods of standing or walking in her job. See Union exhibit U-9. As a result of this initial visit to seek medical attention, the Grievant's doctor provided her a written note explaining that she had chronic tower back and left sacroiliac pain due to a degenerative arthritic condition and recommending that she refrain from long periods of standing or walking in her job. When the Grievant provided this note to the Company
The record is not clear as to who in the Augusta facility the Grievant provided Dr. Boutwell's note. Nevertheless, she was Informed that the Company would not accept Dr. Boutwell's finding and recommendation since he was a chiropractor. she was informed that it was not acceptable because it was from a chiropractor and not a medical doctor; and received a letter dated March 11, 2014, accepting her request as a request for accommodation, explaining the provision of the ADA providing copies of a “Fact Sheet regarding the Disability Accommodation Process” and “Request of Disability Accommodation” form; and requesting specific documentation and information.
The March 11, 2014, unsigned letter from the Company specifically requested: (1) Medical documentation of the impairmeht and how it affects a major life activity…; (2) Specification as to whether or not the condition is permanent or long termed, and if long termed, the approximate duration; and (3) Which of the essential functions outlined in the attached job description are affected by the impairment, and any suggestions your health care provider may have for accommodations that would allow you to perform these duties, if any…. See Employer exhibit E-5. Accordingly, on April 11, 2014, the Grievant went to see an orthopedist who, after examining her, provided a written explanation of her medical condition and recommended that Ms. Wells be returned to her old type forklift where she was able to sit down.
The second doctor Ms. Wells went to see was Dr. Robert C. Gambrell, an orthopedist, who provided a written explanation of her condition and recommendation for accommodation…Specifically providing, Tamela is under my care for lower back pain. She has significant pain in her back and In her left ankle causing her difficulties performing her Job. She also has a history of a left ankle injury that has left her with arthritis in her ankle. Her back and ankle feel better with rest My recommendation would be that she return to her old type of forklift to be able to sit down. She should avoid prolonged standing at work. She could sit for 10-12 hours but should have relative limited standing…. See Union exhibit U-11.

On April 14,2014, the Company again wrote to Ms. Wells outlining the provisions of the Americans with Disability Act (ADA), defining a disability, explaining what is required to be covered and eligible for accommodation; and, acknowledging that on March 21, 2014, she filed a Request for Disability Accommodation providing “That “standing on my legs, feet go numb & pressure on my back, thighs and calves…Would like to use standard sit down truck.’” The letter further explained that in order to make a determination in the case specific medical information was needed,
The letter provided in part…Please provide a physician's statement that includes: (1) Medical documentation stating the duration of time you can continuously stand before you lose feeling in your feet…How long do you need to sit before you can stand again; (2) Medical documentation of the impairment and how it affects your ability to walk/stand when using a stand-up forklift vehicle; (3) Which of the essential functions outlined in the attached job description you cannot perform because standing causes flare-ups of your condition as you stated in your Request for Disability Accommodation, and any suggestions your health care provider may have for accommodation that would allow you to perform the essential functions of your job, if any; and (4) Please specify if the condition is permanent or long term… if long term, please state the approximate duration. See Employer exhibit E-6. The record also shows that during this same time frame the Grievant was also provided a Dart Fitness for Duty form for her doctor to fill out. It is unclear if this from was transmitted as part of the Company's April 14th letter or provided by the local Human Resource Manager, nevertheless the record does show the form was completed by Dr. Gambell. See Union exhibit U-1 and Employer exhibit E-6. and asking that the Grievant provide the listed information as soon as possible.

Accordingly, on April 24, 2014, the Grievant went back to both her chiropractor and orthopedist to obtain the medical documentation/information requested. Both doctors again provided Ms. Wells written statements explaining her medical condition and recommending that the “most obvious simple solution to her problems would be to allow her to return to using a sit down forklift… lf that solution [could not be taken] then while she is operating a standup forklift she should be allowed to get off the forklift for 15-20 minutes every hour to perf[orm] duties or take one of her scheduled rest breaks.”
The Grievant's chiropractor, Dr. Boutwell's April 24, 2014, written statement provided that [Ms.] Wells is under our care for lower back and SI pain. It is our recommendation that she refrain from working longer than one hour without sitting down for a 15 minute period. She is however able to sit for long periods in a work situation, i.e., a 12 hour shift…. See Union exhibit U-12. The Grievants orthopedist, Dr. Gambrell's April 24, 2014, written statement provided in part that [Ms.] Wells is a patient under my care for low back pain and left ankle arthritis. She recently presented for evaluation of exacerbation of her back and ankle pain from driving a stand-up forklift at work. [S]he states that she has been working for the company for 20+ years using a sit down forklift and has had no significant problems performing the duties of her job. [S]he has recently made a change to a stand-up forklift which requires her to keep both feet in the same position for hours at a tim[e] [and] keep both her feet firmly pressed against pedals on the floor of the forklift to keep it operating. Operation of the forklift is primarily with the upper extremities. Due to the unique configuration of the stand-up forklift, as compared to the sit-down forklift [she] experiences significant pain in her back, legs, and ankles which she has never experienced in the past…The most obvious simple solution to her problems would be to allow her to return to using a sit-down forklift If that solution [cannot be provided] then while she is operating a stand-up forklift she should be allowed to get off of the forklift for 15-20 minutes every hour to perf[orm] duties or to take one of her scheduled rest breaks…if she [is] allowed to return to the sit-down forklift she would have no restrictions whatsoever….” See Union exhibit U-13. On April 30, 2014, the Company acknowledged Ms. Wells medical problems as meeting the requirements of the ADA and approved the following accommodation…”While operating the stand-up forklift, [you] will be allowed to get off of the forklift and work on arranging materials, filling out necessary paperwork, and other job duties for 15 minutes after every one hour of standard forklift use.”
The record provides that the Grievant was off work, mostly on medical and/or FMLA leave from March 22 — April 29, 2014…Then on April 30, 2014, received a letter from Ms. Michelle Jones, Dart LOA/ADA Specialist providing… We hope that this accommodation will enable you to perform the essential functions of your job, but we understand that modification is sometimes necessary. Please feel free to contact your supervisor, local HR representative in the Corporate Benefits Department if this accommodation does not prove effective or if over time modifications needed. As always we will review this accommodation on a regular basis to ensure that (1) the accommodation continues to allow you to perform the essential functions of your job and (2) to make any adjustments to the accommodation that are reasonable. Thank you for your cooperation in this process. See Union exhibit U-10.

From approximately March 22 through April 29, 2014, the Grievant was off work on medical and/or Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) leave. When she returned to her regular work schedule on/or about April 30, 2014, Ms. Wells, performed her assigned forklift operator duties using a stand-up forklift and working in accordance with the approved accommodation, one-hour on the lift and fifteen minutes off performing other assigned work.
Testimony from the facility Human Resources director provided that the Grievant's department manager provided Ms. Wells a list of duties to perform within the fifteen minute periods she was off the forklift, including paper work, sweeping, etc.

About a month after returning to working her regular twelve-hour schedule, on May 23, 2014, the Grievant went to her primary care physician, Dr. Newman, for her annual physical. During this examination Dr. Newman inquired about the swelling in the Grievant's legs and ankles, and Ms. Wells explained her work situation. As a result of his examination, Dr. Newman provided Ms. Wells a written statement explaining the results of his examination and recommending that the Grievant not be required to stand all day long and allowed to return to operating a sit-down forklift
The May 23, 2014, written statement from Dr. Newman provided… This letter is in regard to Tamela Wells, a patient I have been following for a number of years. Tamela recently came in with the complaint of bilateral lower-extremity edema which appears to be worse at the end of the day. It is better by the next meaning but not completely eradicated. It is sot accompanied by shortness of breath or chest discomfort. It began after her work changed to where she is now having to stand all day on an upright forklift instead of being able to sit throughout the day. After evaluation, she has been diagnosed with venous insufficiency. As a consequence of this, I have advised her to ear compression stockings daily. It would be better if the patient did not need to stand all day long. This is clearly contributing to her underlying problem, and would be markedly better for her to be able to go back to a sit-down forklift…. See Union exhibit U-15.

On June 24, 2014, the Grievant provided the Company Dr. Newman's May 23rd written statement providing that “…would be better if the patient did not have to stand all day long” and again suggesting a return to a sit-down forklift. Since this amounted to a new accommodation request the LOA/ADA Specialist sent a letter to the Grievant that day requesting further information.
The June 24, 2014, letter again explained the ADA provisions and eligibility requirements then provided… On June 24, 2014, you submitted a doctor's note from Danny Newman MD stating that …has advised to wear leg compression stockings daily…it would be better if the patient did not need to stand all day long…. [And providing further] in order to make a determination in this case we will need some additional inforiflatiun. Please provide the following documentation/information to me as soon as possible so that we may provide you with a prompt and appropriate decision on your request for accommodation. Please provide a physician's statement that includes: Medical documentation stating the duration of time you can continuously stand…How long do you need to sit before you can stand again; Medical documentation of the Impairment end how it affects your ability to walk/stand when using a standup fork lift vehicle; Which of the essential functions outlined in the attached job description you cannot perform because standing causes flare-ups of your condition as you stated in your original Request for Disability Accommodation dated March 11, 2014, and any suggestions your health care provider may have for accommodations that would allow you to perform the essential functions of your job, if any; Please specify if the condition is permanent or long-term. if long term, please state the approximate duration… See Employer exhibit E-7. According to the Company, the Grievant failed to acknowledge or respond to the June 24th request So after thirty-days passed with no communication from the Grievant, on July 25, 2014, the LOA/ADA Specialist sent a letter informing the Grievant that the request was being closed based on the Grievant stalling the interactive process, but that she could restart the process at any time by submitting the requested information.
The July 25, 2014, letter concluded…Without your collaboration the interactive process is halted and we are unable to make a determination or move forward with the ADA process. We will gladly resume this process once the necessary Information has been submitted. While this process is halted we are unable to continue any temporary accommodations that may have been provided….” See Employer exhibit E-8.

The Grievant did go back to see Dr. Newman on August 7,2014, because he had scheduled her for a follow-up appointment. On this visit Dr. Newman gave Ms. Well a second letter providing that she could not stand for more than one hour without being able to be seated for thirty minutes, and recommending that she be able to return to a sit-down forklift
This August 7, 2014, letter from Dr. Newman provided: This letter is in regard to Tamela Wells, a patient I have been following in my office for the last several years. Tamela presented to my office on May 23 with complaints of increasing bilateral lower extremity edema. This is a new problem. It seemed to occur since she began standing at her forklift all day long as compared to previously when she was able to sit. Since that time she has developed 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema which persists throughout the night and is sometimes better in the meaning but is certainly worse by the end of the day. At the time she was advised to wear TED hose daily and to be able to sit and keep her legs elevated as often as possible. In my opinion she cannot continuously stand for more than one hour without being able to be seated for at least 30 minutes in order to keep this from being a consistent problem. If indeed this continues she will have worsening swelling in her legs bilaterally that can lead to venous insufficiency and chronic swelling and edema as well as pain. If the patient would be allowed to sit while working on her forklift I think it would essentially eradicate this problem [or] if she could take frequent breaks to keep her legs elevated. At this point this appears to be a permanent long-term condition although it has only been ongoing for the last several months…. Here the record shows that the Grievant provided Dr. Newman's second letter to the local Human Resources (HR) manager on or about August 18, 2014.

Almost a month and a half later, when the Grievant reported to work the meaning of October 3, 2014, she was instructed to report to the facilities' personnel office. Upon arriving at the personnel office, the local HR manager asked Ms. Wells if she had received a letter in September from Dart Container. After responding that she had not received any letter from Dart, the local HR manager explained that Ms. Well's request for further accommodation was denied. The local HR manager then called her Regional HR manager and the two HR managers and the Grievant had a three-way discussion about the Grievant's situation. This discussion concluded with the Grievant being told to go home, go back to see her doctor(s) to see if there were any other accommodations that could be suggested; and, that they [the local HR manager, the regional HR manager, and the Grievant] would have another conversation on October 10th.
The September letter the local HR manager asked whether or not the Grievant had received, which she then explained to Ms. Wells was the Company's formal denial of her August 18, 2014, submittal of medical documentation and request for further accommodation, was actually received in the mail delivered after she returned home from work on October 3rd. That letter, from Dart LOA/ADA Specialist, Shari Sweeney, provided as follows: …On 8/18/14 you submitted medical documentation requesting the following disability accommodation: to use a sit-down type forklift, to work from a seated position for at least 30 minutes after each hour worked in a standing position, [and] frequent breaks to keep your legs elevated… After reviewing your request and engaging in an interactive dialogue, unfortunately, we find we must deny your request for the following reasons: 1. Due to the safety and ergonomic concerns encountered with the sit-down type of fork-lifts a safety-based decision was previously made to eliminate them from the plant by the end of 2014. There currently are 2-3 sit-down type of forklifts remaining in the distribution center which will also be eliminated by the end of the year for safety reasons. Despite the pending elimination of said fork-lifts deemed to be less safe, we still made inquiries of employees in those positions as to whether they might voluntarily exchange positions with you. We found no employees willing to make the exchange. Therefore, a sit-down type of fork-lift is not available. (2) After reviewing your current job functions, there are not a sufficient number of duties that can be done from a seated position to fill 30 minutes after each 1 hour worked standing on your feet. The ability to stand regularly (up to 67-100% of the time) is an essential function of your job. Under the ADA a qualified individual is a person who is able to perform all of the essential functions of the job with or without accommodation. (3) At this time there are no open positions for which you are qualified, nor are we aware of any such positions opening in the foreseeable future…We believe we have made every effort to provide reasonable accommodation as requested and have exhausted all possibilities. Consequently, at this time we believe you are unable to perform the essential functions of your position With or without reasonable accommodation…While we have made every effort to include you in the accommodation process it is possible that you have additional information that you feel we should consider. If so please present this additional information to your HR representative for review…Thank you for your cooperation in this process…. During the meeting/discussion with the local HR manager and Regional HR manager the Grievant inquired about being moved to a packer or production job, or being moved to the warehouse. All rejected by the HR folks claiming there were no vacant positions for which Ms. Wells qualified. At the end of the meeting/discussion Ms. Wells was told to go home and they would have another conference call on October 10th…That they would call her.

On October 10, 2014, the local HR and Regional HR managers called the Grievant. The Regional HR manager asked Ms. Wells if she had been back to see her doctor. Ms. Wells said she had. The Regional HR manager then asked if there were any changes or any restrictions lifted. The Grievant responded that there were no changes in her medical condition and the restriction continued as previously explained by her doctor, Dr. Newman. The Regional HR manager then told Ms. Wells, “since [her] doctor didn't lift [her] restrictions that they [the Company] did not have a job for [her then] or in the future…” and said good bye.

Later the same day, October 10, 2014. the Business Agent for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT), Local 528, emailed the Dart/Solo local HR manager requesting information about Ms. Wells' termination.
On or about October 15, 2014, the Grievant received a letter from the local HR manager, dated October 10, 2014, identified as a separation of employment that provided:

blockquote.p:
‘“Attached you will find your “State of Georgia Department of Labor Separation Notice”
The attached State of Georgia Department of Labor Separation Notice, dated October 10, 2014, showed the reason for separation as being unable to return from leave that you may take to your local Department of Labor Unemployment Office to file for Unemployment Benefits.

You will also receive a packet from the Solo Cup Company Benefits department that will explain your available options for your current insurance coverage. Your benefits terminate at midnight on the date of your separation of employment
If any further information is needed please feel free to contact the local Human Resources department…”

body.p: Subsequently, on October 16,2014, Ms. Wells, with the assistance of the Union, filed her formal grievance, citing Article 9 and 10 of the parties' CBA and providing:

blockquote.p: “On Oct 15, 2014, I received a separation notice from Dart/Solo Cup signed 10-10-14 that I no longer was employed at Dart/Solo Cup. This separation notice is improper and unfair and unjust The Company did not have just cause to terminate me. Separation notice states that my reason for separation was unable to return from leave. I was not on leave. It also states that my last day worked was 9-10-14. I request to be allowed to drive a sit down forklift in the warehouse and was denied by Jennifer Davis. [Remedy Requested] To be made whole for all back wages and benefits.”

ftnote.para: Throughout the summation of the parties' position the Arbitrator has chosen to not show every cited reference to testimony as recorded/documented on the Arbitrator's audio file, copies of which were provided to each party for their reference and use, or to list each legal or reference citation…Only those references and/or citations the Arbitrator deems significant will be documented in the endnotes. Nevertheless, the failure to note any reference or citation does not mean that the Arbitrator has not read and fully considered the evidence presented by the parties.

body.p: The Company/Employer offers that the issues to be addressed by the Arbitrator are:

li.p: Did Company's management have the right to change the forklift equipment used in the Augusta, Georgia facility in an effort to improve ergonomic and safety results, and if not what shall be the remedy?
Was Grievant discriminated against because of her alleged disability in violation of Article 27 of the Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA), and, if so, what shall be the remedy?

body.p:
The Company also offers that the relevant provisions of the CBA are: Article 2-Recognition, Article 5-Management Rights, Article 9-Job Posting, Article 10-Complaints, Article 11-Arbitration, Article 27-Feir Employment Practices and Equal Opportunities, Article 31-Safety and Health, and Article 34-Scope of Agreement
See Arbitrator/Joint exhibit AJ-3 Labor Agreement Between SOLO Cup Operating Corporation, Augusta, Georgia and The International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT) Local 528, effective April 1, 2012 through March 31, 2016…Where the Arbitrator deems it necessary for clarity provisions and/or excerpts from the parties' collective bargaining agreement will be cited either in the text of this decision/award or in its endnotes. However, not showing the full text or excerpt of any provision does not mean the Arbitrator has not read, noted, or referred to the parties CBA. The Arbitrator Incorporates all of the parties CBA by reference in this decision/award.
The Company's position and arguments are summarized as follows.

The Company's version of the events leading up to the Grievant's termination is basically the same as presented above. However, it stresses that in 2013, the Plant Manager of the Augusta facility was charged with the responsibility of replacing the leased forklifts used in the facility with purchased forklifts. Accordingly, in keeping with the Company's safety-focused culture, the Plant Manager, in conjunction with the facility's safety experts, investigated the best forklift options for the facility. After considering data about the history of forklift-related accidents and injuries in the facility
See Union exhibit U-6., the physical configuration of the workspace in the facility, OSHA ergonomic guidance, and research related to the. ergonomic benefits of a stand-up style forklift, the decision was made to replace the leased, sit-down style forklifts with stand-up style forklifts.

According to the Company; the stand-up style forklifts offer significant-ergonomic benefis and the compact design that is better suited to a workspace like the Augusta facility, which requires a tighter turning radius for safe forklift operation. Additionally, the stand-up forklift provides greater visibility, increasing the operator's ability to maneuver through the work area safely.
See Employer exhibit 1.

The Company argues that under the provisions of Article 5 of the parties' CBA as conceded by the Union in its opening statement at the arbitration hearing, the Company had the right to select equipment for use in the facility, and the selection of. stand-up.styla forklifta was within the scope of that right.

According to the Company, the introduction of stand-up forklifts was announced to the Augusta workforce in early 2014, and the safety and ergonomic benefits were explained to the workforce at that time. Training was conducted with production forklift operators in March 2014; and after receiving certification on the stand-up forklifts, operators were encouraged to work partial shifts on the new lifts to allow workers an adjustment period.
As to the Grievant's claim that the Company failed to properly accommodate her, the Company explains that

li.p: In March 2014, when the Grievant complained of back, leg, and ankle pain; requested a leave of absence; and, that she be allowed to use a sit-down style forklift as a disability accommodation when she returned to work.

Here the Company maintains it followed its standard procedures, and assigned a dedicated Leave of Absence/Americans with Disabilities Act Specialist (LOA/ADA Specialist) in the corporate office to review and respond to Grievant's request(s). Following internal procedures, as well as the letter and spirit of the ADA the assigned LOA/ADA Specialist reviewed the Grievant's request - Including the Grievant's preferred accommodation, a return to using a sit-down style forklift; as well as, the alternative accommodation of working for fifteen minutes off of the forklift for every hour spent working on the forklift.

Based on the return to work restrictions from the Grievant's medical doctor, the Company determined that it could provide accommodation for the Grievant, but not her preferred accommodation — a return to the old-style, sit-down forklift — because the LOA/ADA Specialist determined it would impede the facility's ability to realize the important ergonomic and safety gains sought in the switch to stand-up forklifts.

Instead, the Company granted the doctor's alternate accommodation, working for fifteen minutes off of the forklift for every hour spent working on the forklift, and implemented that accommodation upon the Grievant's return to work on May 2,2014.

On August 18, 2014, the Company received a darifying doctor's note dated August 7, 2014, stating that it was based on the Grievant's May 23,2014, doctor's visit This new note indicated that the Grievant was unable to stand for more than one hour after which she would need to be seated for at least thirty-minutes and keep her legs elevated. The restriction was identified as permanent.

The Company maintains its response to the August 18,2014 request was slowed by the fact that the LOA/ADA Specialist who had been working on the Grievant's case resigned her position mere days before the letter was received. And, the newly assigned LOA/ADA Specialist had to get acquainted with the case. The Company explains that the new LOA/ADA Specialist again worked with local management safety, and human resources professionals to investigate the feasibility of reintroducing a sit-down style forklift into the production area of the facility as a possible accommodation. However, after significant review, including review of actual, year-to-date safety gains in the facility including the fact that there had been six forklift-related incident reports filed in calendar year 2013, and only one year-to-date in 2014, the determination was made that stand-up forklifts were the safest machines for the production area of the facility and that the safety risks of reintroducing a sit-down forklift were too great and would reverse the significant gains that had been made in the safety results of the facility.

The company argues that jeopardizing the safety of other employees in the workplace when it had announced the safety goals of the new forklifts, and had proof of the benefits realized from the switch to stand-up forklifts, was determined to be an undue burden on business operations.
Review of the doctor's alternative accommodation, that the Grievant would need to be allowed to sit for thirty-minutes with her legs elevated after each hour standing, was deemed unviable.
Finally, as required under the ADA the Company considered whether there were open positions meeting her medical restrictions within the facility for which the Grievant was qualified. There were none.

Because separation of employment was an unwelcome outcome, the Company claims it provided the Grievant with an additional opportunity to provide new accommodation options for consideration. On October 3, 2014, the local HR Manager and Regional HR Business Partner met with the Grievant to communicate the outcome of the ADA accommodation review, and to ask her if she had any additional accommodation ideas. When she did not have any immediately, they informed her that they would give her one week to speak to her doctor and inform them of any additional accommodation ideas. She was informed that she would be off work on leave during that time period.

On October 10,2014, the HR Manager and Regional HR Business Partner spoke to the Grievant to determine if she had any additional accommodation ideas they could consider. She reported that she did not. At that point, with no further accommodation opportunities to consider, the Grievant was informed that her employment was being separated.

body.p: The Company argues that the plain language of Article 5; Section 1 of the CBA allows management the right “to change or eliminate existing methods of operations, equipment or facilities….” Furthermore, it argues the Union confirmed this clear right in its opening statement at the Arbitration hearing when the Union's Counsel commented that the “Company does have the right to select equipment”

As to the Union's argument that the Company abused its discretion by selecting the stand-up forklift to replace the sit-down style forklifts based on the fact that there have been lawsuits filed against the manufacturer of the lifts selected - The Company maintains that even a cursory reading of the cases cited by the Union
See Union exhibit U-1. indicates that none of the cases provide a decision on the merits and that they do not in any way conclude the forklifts selected for use in the Augusta facility are unsafe; and that any contention otherwise would appear to be irrationally misleading. The Company then argues that

li.p: The McEuin v. Crown Equipment Corp., case involved an earlier model of the Crown stand up forklift that was replaced in 2007 by the newer models in use in the Augusta facility;
In the Walden v. Crown Equipment Corp., case the court considered not the design of the Crown stand up forklift, but rather Crown's appeal on the admission of certain expert testimony;

. In Congilaro v. Crown Equipment Corp., Crown motioned to exclude two of the plaintiffs expert witnesses and Its motion for summary judgment Ultimately, the court disqualified one of the expert witnesses in this decision What the Union did not provide in the Arbitration hearing was the April 2013 jury trial, resulting in a finding in favor of Crown, or the plaintiffs September 2013 appeal of the jury decision which was also decided-in favor of Grown
2013 WL 5346714;
In Robinson v. Crown Equipment Corp., Crown moved to exclude plaintiffs expert witness, and was denied. No merits decision could be found;
In Malbrough v. Crown Equipment Corp., Crown moved for, and was denied, summary judgment No decision on the merits could be found;

In Martin v. Crown Equipment Corp., Crown moved for, and was granted, summary judgment as to punitive damages. Further, this decision outlines the American National Standards Institute's (“ANSI”) voluntary power industrial truck standards for stand-up foridrfts. ANSI's safety standards, which are followed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (“OSHA”), read as follows: Stand-ups, rear entry end control, narrow aisle, and reach trucks shall be designed with open operator compartments to permit ingress and egress. This allows the operator, where possible, a free and easy egress from the truck in the event of an imminent tip-over or of-the-dock accident in finding for Crown on the punitive damages issue, the court noted that “Crown's compliance with ANSI's highly-respected standards, which OSHA has adopted, is strong evidence of the reasonableness of Crown's conduct” It is difficult to imagine how the Union contends that Crown's reasonableness in design is proof of abuse of discretion in selecting a similar style forklift for the Company's Augusta facility;

In Mahon v. Crown Equipment Corp., Crown moved for reconsideration of an earlier denial of summary judgment based on the decision in Martin, above. The court denied the motion based on the fact that Martin was not binding precedent in California. No merits decision was available; and finally,

In Dymnioski v. Crown Equipment Corp., the court found that the plaintiff failed to state a valid claim, and the decision provided by the Union simply allowed the plaintiff leave to amend the claim. However, in the successor case the court granted summary judgment to Crown.
2013 WL 2297035

body.p: After commenting on the cases cited by the Union at hearing, the Company concludes that even if the case law cited did support the Union's contention, which it surely does not, the proper standard of review regarding the safety of equipment selected under a company's management rights prerogative is merely one of good faith as defined in Scott Paper Company, Southern Operators and United Paperworkers International Union, Local 423 (FMCS Case No. 79K/02763; Simon, 1979) which found:

blockquote.p: “So long as the agreement does not restrict management regarding a specific act or action leading to efficiency, and MORE RECENTLY safety, is that the management of the company has a fixed obligation to reduce unnecessary cost and to provide the safest possible working conditions for all of its employees. It is noted, however, that the management decision must be made in good faith and that it acted reasonably in view of the particular existing conditions and has not discriminated or infringed upon the legitimate rights of any employee. (Emphasis in original).

body.p: The Company argues that it exercised good faith decision-making in selecting the Crown stand-up forklifts by researching forklift options, safety and ergonomic issues related to forklift use, the layout of the production areas of the Augusta facility, and the accident reports involving forklift trucks in the facility. The research to which the Augusta, Georgia Plant Manager testified indicated that stand-up lifts offer a significant ergonomic benefit to the driver because the step height is lower to enter and exit the lift, entry and exit is limited to one movement rather than four to enter a sit-down lift, and there is no need for the driver to twist her trunk to view the direction of travel when driving with forks trailing. Further research indicated that the smaller footprint and tighter turning radius of the standup forklifts would likely reduce building damage, and, more importantly, the risk of a pedestrian collision in the small aisle ways in certain areas of the plant

While the Union claimed repeatedly during the arbitration hearing that there was no history of injuries or accidents in the Augusta facility when sit-down style forklifts were in use, the Union's own exhibit six contradicts this assertion In fact, the exhibit indicates that there were ten incident reports filed involving the use of sit-down style forklifts preceding the introduction of stand-up style forklifts.

The Company's maintains that reviewing the equipment selection decision under the proper standard of review — compliance with the CBA and good faith — clearly demonstrates the Company's compliance, and requires a finding that the first issue in this Arbitration must be decided in the affirmative.

The Company agrees that it has an obligation to comply with both the federal Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Fair Employment Practices and Equal Opportunities provisions of the CBA Furthermore, it agrees this obligation includes the ADA'S requirement to provide reasonable accommodation for a qualified individual with a disability to allow her to perform the essential functions of her position.

As summarized above, the Grievant made a request for an ADA-covered accommodation related to her use of the newly introduced stand-up forklift in March 2014. This request was handled by one of the Company's dedicated LOA/ADA Specialists, who engaged in an interactive process to determine and assess possible reasonable accommodations. Ultimately, the Grievant's doctor indicated two accommodation possibilities that he believed would meet Grievant's physical limitations while allowing her to perform the job duties listed in her job description. The doctor suggested either (1) a return to a sit-down style fork lift, or (2) allowing the Grievant to spend 15 minutes performing duties off the forklift after every hour spent working on the stand-up forklift

Accordingly, the LOA/ADA Specialist determined that it was best to offer the Grievant the doctor's second option as an approved accommodation rather than reintroducing equipment that the company had deemed to be less safe for the work environment. This decision was supported by the research that the Plant Manager had conducted on the benefits of the stand-up style forklifts in the Augusta work environment and by consideration of the potential for liability to the company if it reintroduced the equipment that had been deemed less safe and later a forklift/pedestrian accident did occur.

Here the Company points out that while the ADA requires an employer provide reasonable accommodations to qualified individuals with disabilities, an employer is not required to provide the requester with her preferred accommodation. In Lewis v. Zilog, inc., the court held that an individual with a disability “is not entitled to the accommodation of her choice, but only to a reasonable accommodation.”
908 F. Supp. 931, 948 (1995)

As outlined above, in late June 2014
See Union exhibit U-15 and Employer exhibit E-7., the Grievant provided a new doctor's note that indicated that “it would be markedly better for [Grievant] to go back to a sit-down style forklift” Recognizing this as a new accommodation request under the ADA the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist provided Grievant with new ADA accommodation paperwork. After a month had passed with no response from the Grievant a letter was sent to her indicating that she had stalled the interactive accommodation process, but that she could begin the process again at any time by responding to the previous request for information.

On August 18, 2014, Grievant provided a new doctor's note dated August 7, 2015, that was responsive to the Company's June request for information. The August 7 note identified the Grievant's need to be off her feet with her legs elevated as often as possible, and indicated that having to stand all day was exacerbating her medical condition. The doctor indicated two accommodation possibilities that he believed would meet the Grievant's physical limitations: (1) being seated for thirty minutes after each hour worked on the forklift, or (2) a return to a sit-down style forklift.

Again, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist considered possible accommodations. As for providing a thirty-minute break each hour to allow the Grievant to sit with her feet elevated, the LOA/ADA Specialist determined that the request was unreasonable under the ADA The LOA/ADA Specialist then considered the request that the Grievant be allowed to return to a sit-down style forklift Again, the conclusion was that this accommodation would not be granted As before, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist reviewed the safety gains that had been made in the facility in the period since stand-up forklifts had been introduced and found that significant gains had in fact been achieved. As can be seen in the occupational injury reports submitted as Union exhibit six; there were six incident reports filed due to forklift accidents during calendar year 2013, and only one in the first eight months of 2014. Again considering the safety goals of the company, and the liability and risk of reintroducing equipment that had been found to be less safe, the LOA/ADA Specialist determined that reintroduction of a sit-down style forklift would be an undue hardship
Undue hardship is defined In the ADA as:
In general. - The term undue hardship means an action requiring significant difficulty or expense, when considered in light of the factors set forth in subparagraph (B).
Factors to be considered in determining whether an accommodation would impose an undue hardship on a covered
entity, factors to be considered include:
the nature and cost of the accommodation needed under this chapter;
the overall financial resources of the facility or facilities involved In the provision of the reasonable accommodation; the number of persons employed at such facility; the effect on expenses and resources, or the impact otherwise of such accommodation upon the operation of the facility;
the overall financial resources of the covered entity; the overall size of the business of a covered entity with respect to the number of its employees; the number, type, and location of its facilities; and
the type of operation or operations of the covered entity, including the composition, structure, and functions of the workforce of such entity; the geographic separateness, administrative, or fiscal relationship of the facility or facilities in question to the covered entity.
on the operations of the business under the ADA

In both the initial review for accommodation and the second review, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialists' determinations were grounded in the following rationale: (1) potentially jeopardizing a facility's safety program by reversing safety-specific initiatives, particularly when said program is showing positive results, is inherently imprudent; and (2) future injuries on reintroduced sit-down forklifts could expose the Company to untold liability after publically broadcasting to its workers that said forklifts were a less safe equipment option. The LOA/ADA Specialists' reliance on speculative, yet foreseeable, harm was not an unreasonable approach, particularly since the law encourages proactive measures, and ‘does not require [an employer] to wait for a serious injury before eliminating a direct threat” Jarvis v. potter, 500 F.3d 1113,1124 (10th Cir. 2007).

After both, the initial and second accommodation requests determination was made, in accordance with the requirements of the ADA, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist continued to work with management to try to determine any other possible accommodations that would allow the Grievant to perform the essential functions of her job. This included looking for open positions in the facility for which the Grievant was qualified: none were identified; as well as consideration of a transfer to a forklift operator position in the warehouse where sit-down style lifts were still in use, even though they were scheduled for replacement with stand-up style forklifts within two to three months. Unfortunately, there were no open positions in the warehouse.

However, in an attempt to make every effort to find a way to accommodate the Grievant's physical limitations, which is legally required to demonstrate a good faith interactive process under the ADA the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist directed the forklift drivers in the warehouse be asked if they would be willing to swap positions with a forklift operator in the production area. Here, the Company maintains that asking the warehouse forklift drivers to consider swapping positions was a function of the ADA interactive process, directed by the LOA/ADA Specialist in order to fulfill the Company's legal obligations under federal law, an issue beyond the scope of the CBA And, the Company agues the solicitation was not intended, and in fact did not encroach upon the Union's right as the exclusive bargaining agent on matters contained in the CBA According to the Company, under the ADA, the LOA/ADA Specialist has a legal obligation to explore all conceivable accommodation options, and that responsibility cannot legally be constrained or indicated to a third party. Nevertheless, despite the inquiry, no employee was willing to swap positions.

At this point the LOA/ADA Specialist recognized that the Company had no further options to consider and drafted a letter to the Grievant indicating that it could not offer any reasonable accommodations to allow her to perform the essential functions of her job. The local HR manager and regional HR business partner met with Grievant on October 3,2014, to discuss the outcome of the accommodation review, and to determine if she had any additional accommodation ideas that the Company had not yet considered: Grievant reported that she did not have any additional ideas. The local HR manager and regional HR business partner told Grievant that they would give her a week to determine if there were any other accommodations that she would like the Company to consider. The Grievant was not actively at work for that one week period.
Grievants time records offered as Appendix H of the Company's Post-hearing brief,

On October 10, 2014, the local HR manager and regional HR business partner again spoke with the Grievant to determine if she had any additional accommodation ideas that the Company could consider; she did not At that time, the Company separated Ms. Wells' employment.

The Company points out that during closing remarks, the Union's Counsel contended that because all of the Grievant's doctors had stated that a transition back to a sit-down style forklift would be beneficial to her medical condition, it was a reasonable accommodation However, the Company maintains that is not the proper standard of review under the ADA Instead, an ADA a accommodation is reasonable if it allows the employee to perform the essential functions of the job without undue hardship on the operation of the business. Just as, according to the Company, the Union appears to believe that if an individual files a lawsuit claiming a manufacturing defect there is proof of a manufacturing defect; it appears also to believe that if a doctor makes a recommendation for a possible accommodation (based on medical knowledge, not business operation knowledge), it makes the suggestion a reasonable accommodation under the ADA. According to the Company, neither of these beliefs is accurate.

The Company argues that in reviewing the totality of the record, it is indisputable the Company held a reasonable belief that (1) a stand-up forklift was a safer piece of equipment for its specific work environment, and (2) that returning a sit-down lift to the work environment would pose a significant risk of substantial harm to the health and safety of the Augusta workforce.

Establishing its reasonable belief that the stand-up lift was the safer alternative, the Company offered uncontroverted testimony that its Plant Manager led an effort to investigate the safest forklift options for the facility. The effort and investigation was precipitated by the pending termination of leased forklifts and the decision was made after considering data about the history of forklift-related accidents and injuries in the facility, the physical configuration of the work environment, OSHA ergonomic guidance, and research related to the ergonomic benefits of a stand-up style forklift. This thoughtful review took into account the ergonomic benefits, compact design, and tighter turning radius of stand-up forklifts. The review and decision were not influenced by any single employee, but rather was made for the collective good and safety of the workforce.

The ultimate decision on the reasonableness of reintroducing a sit-down lift to the work environment fell to the Company's Leave and Disability Manager. This manager's testimony likewise established a reasonable belief that returning a sit-down lift to the work environment would pose a significant risk of substantial harm to health and safety of the Augusta workforce. The Leave and Disability Manager's testimony established her determination was made in good-faith. Even the Union's Counsel acknowledged such in his closing remarks, stating that she was free from ill intent in making her determination.

The Company acknowledges that the Union, and perhaps even the Arbitrator, may disagree with its underlying belief that the stand-up lift was the safer option or that the risk of reintroducing the sit-down lift to the work environment posed enough risk that doing so would pose an undue hardship.

Importantly, however, such disagreement, from Grievant and Fact Finder alike, is legally immaterial in determining whether the Company's reasonable belief affords is an affirmative defense to claims of disability discrimination. As the 10* Circuit Court of Appeals recently held in EEOC v. Beverage Distributors, LLC, an employer can avoid liability by establishing its reasonable belief that an employee posed a significant risk to the health and safety of me workforce. (780 F.3d 1018 (2015)). See also Jarvis v. Potter (stating that the fact-finder does not independently assess whether it believes that the employee posed a direct threat, but determines [instead] whether the employer's decision was objectively reasonable.) The court in EEOC v. Beverage Distributors held: In sum, Beverage Distributors could avoid liability by showing that it reasonably determined that: (1) Mr. Sungaila posed a significant risk of substantial harm to the health or safety of Mr. Sungaila and/or other employees; and (2) risk could not be eliminated or reduced by reasonable accommodation.

Applying the Court's rationale in EEOC v. Beverage Distributors to the present matter, the Company's reasonably held belief that; (1) a stand-up forklift was a safer piece of equipment for its specific work environment; and (2) that returning a sit-down lift to the work environment would pose a significant risk of substantial harm to health and safety of the Augusta workforce, should absolve it of liability, regardless of how much Monday meaning quarterbacking is done around its aforementioned reasonable beliefs and determinations.

As for the Union's argument regarding bumping rights - Citing Article 9, Section 4 of the CBA the Union contends that the Grievant should have been moved to the warehouse rather than terminated because she had a right to bump a warehouse forklift operator based on her seniority. Alternatively, the Union contends that the Grievant should have been able to bump into a Group 1 position.

According to the company, this argument is net supported by the clear text of the CBA. Article 9, Section 4 which allows an employee in a Group 2 position (which includes both production and warehouse forklift operators) to “bid down or laterally for bona fide health reasons…” Here according to the Company, the use of file word “bid”distinguishes the right in Section 4 from the right to ‘bump” an employee that is defined in Article 9, Section 1. According to the Company, Section 1 allows “[e]mployees in the same department and classification” to “move to the shift of their preference based upon seniority.” Accordingly, the Company maintains that the use of ‘bid” in Section 4 requires an open position to which the employee can bid; and according to the Company there were no open forklift operator positions in the warehouse. Further, according to the Company, bumping as defined in Section 1 requires that the employee bumping a less senior co-worker, must be in the same department and classification. On this point the Company maintains that while the forklift operators in production and warehouse are in the same pay classification as demonstrated in the wage rate schedule in the CBA, they are in distinct departments as evidenced by unique job descriptions and, importantly, by the Grievart's insistence to the LOA/ADA Specialist during at least five phone calls that the warehouse forklift operator job description that the LOA/ADA Specialist provided to her with her ADA and FMLA paperwork was “nothing like what she does on a daily basis.” For the Company, it is troubling that during the Grievant's cross examination in the arbitration hearing, when there is a benefit to an arbitration finding that the warehouse Grievant denied making any statement that the warehouse job description was not the same as her position.
For the foregoing reasons, the Company respectfully requests that the Arbitrator DENY the grievance.
The Union/Grievant offers that the issue to be addressed by the Arbitrator is:

li.p: Whether there was “just cause” for the discharge of the Grievant? If not, what is the appropriate remedy?

body.p:
The Union also offers that the relevant provisions of the CBA are: Article 5-Management Rights, Article 8-Seniority, Article 9-Job Posting, Article 20-Leave of Absence, Article 27-Fair Employment Practices and Equal Opportunities, and Article 35-Separabifity.
See Arbitrator/Joint exhibit AJ-3 Labor Agreement Between SOLO Cup Operating Corporation, Augusta, Georgia and The International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT) Local 528, effective April 1, 2012 through March 31, 2016…Where the Arbitrator deems it necessary for clarity provisions and/or excerpts from the parties' collective bargaining agreement will be cited either in the text of this decision/award or in its endnotes. However, not showing the full text or excerpt of any provision does not mean the Arbitrator has not read, noted, or referred to the parties CBA The Arbitrator incorporates all of the parties CBA by reference in this decision/award.
The Union's position and arguments are summarized as follows.

According to the Union, the facts in this case are simple and straightforward. The Grievant and her doctors all requested, due to her severe back and ankle problems, that she be granted an accommodation in the equipment that she used to perform her forklift job. The accommodation request was for a sit-down forklift. The evidence shows that Grievant and her coworkers had successfully used sit-down forklifts for over twenty-five years with no serious injuries or accidents. The Employer denied these requests for accommodations solely on the grounds that the Crown stand-up lifts which the Employer acquired are safer and ergonomically better for the forklift drivers. However, the overwhelming record evidence shows the opposite. Indeed, Crown stand-up forklifts, for over a decade, have been the subject of repeated lawsuits where forklift drivers have lost limbs and have been seriously injured due to the fact that these lifts do not adequately protect the forklift drivers. Moreover, OSHA has posted a warning on its website stating the stand-up lifts can and do cause injuries due to inadequate protection due to “under-ride” hazards. The evidence also shows that the Grievant and a number of her coworkers experienced severe physical problems while driving the stand-up lifts. The evidence is overwhelming that the safety and ergonomic concerns raised by the Employer in the denial of the Grievant's accommodation requests are pre-textual and not supported in reason or fact. Moreover, the denial of the Grievant and her doctors' accommodation requests resulted in her involuntary separation and discharge. Therefore, the Union submits that the discharge of the Grievant is absolutely unjust and that she should be reinstated, granted the accommodation that she requested and made whole for ail of her losses.

The Union points out that the Grievant was hired by Dart Container Corporation, Solo Cup Operating facility in Augusta, Georgia on March 29,1982. She worked thirty-two years, her entire work career, with this Employer. In addition, she was the Union steward at this plant since 1990, approximately twenty-four years and during the majority of this time she was a forklift driver. Furthermore, the evidence shows that during her entire tenure of employment, the Grievant has never been given any major discipline. She has never previously been suspended or discharged. She has never had an accident driving the forklift. And, the Grievant was the most senior forklift driver at the Augusta Plant at the time of her discharge.

The Union maintains that sit-down lifts have been used at the Augusta Plant for over twenty-four years prior to 2014, and during this entire period, there has not been one single OSHA reportable accident or injury caused by the sit-down fork lifts. Furthermore, Union witnesses at the hearing testified that the sit-down lifts have been comfortable to drive and use; and forklift drivers have not suffered foot, knee or ankle problems with the sit-down forklifts.

Additionally, the Union paints out that in February of 2014, when the Employer announced that it was going to replace the sit down forklifts with stand-up lifts; at least three sit-down lifts were to be retained for a short period of time. These three sit-down lifts were to be kept for work associated with the warehouse until the end of 2014. Then one sit-down lift which is a scissor lift was to be kept permanently.

The Union also argues that all of the forklift drivers at the Augusta plant are in the same job classification and the Grievant was the most senior forklift driver. According to the Union, one group of forklift drivers operates forklifts which keep the production lines supplied with material to produce the product. These forklift drivers remove the product from the extrusion area of the plant and transport it to the print area and the warehouse areas of the plant for further processing and/or storage. These forklift drivers also deliver material to the trophy room where most of the finished product is produced. The other group of drivers stock finished product in the warehouse or on trailers. The Union contends that while the Grievant's normal job assignment was to service the plant, the evidence shows she has performed the forklift job in all areas of the plant and warehouse and that she is fully capable to perform all aspects of the forklift job. The Union further argues that basically, all of the forklift drivers perform the same type of work, hauling and moving product and supplies and all are within the same job classification. They merely have different areas to service.

The Grievant and all the other forklift drivers who serviced the plant were provided stand-up Clark 5500 forklifts in February of 2014 to drive and use in the performance of their jobs. Three sit-down lifts were retained to service the warehouse and the sit down scissor lift was kept to move rolls of paper.
While the basic facts about the events occurring from February to October 2014 outlined above in the Background section are not disputed, like the Company, the Union presented its version as follows:

blockquote.p: • The Grievant began driving a stand-up Clark 5500 lift in February of 2014. She testified that she was given very minimal training in the operation of this lift. This training was sufficient to enable her to satisfy the OSHA forklift license requirement.

As pointed out above, by March 2014, the Grievant began experiencing problems with her back, ankle and legs. She testified that her feet felt like they were “on fire,” that her ankles were severely aching, she was experiencing swelling, and also suffering with severe back pain.
