The Grievant further testified that during the some twenty-four years she had driven the sit-down lift, she had never experienced any of these type problems, at least to the extent that she was having while driving the stand-up lift

To operate the Clark 5500 standup lift, the Grievant, and another forklift operator both, testified you are required to stand in the same position on the lift with both feet on the floor for the entire twelve-hour work shift According to the Union, testimony confirmed that it was this standing for an extended period of time that caused the Grievant's major discomfort and problems significant enough for her to seek medical attention.
In March 2014, the Grievant went to her chiropractor Dr. Darrell Boutwell for her problems; and Dr. Boutwell provided her a written statement explaining that

Ms. Wells had been a patient since 2003; and she has chronic tower back and left sacroiliac pain due to degenerative arthritic condition. It is our strong recommendation that Ms. Wells refrain from long periods of standing or walking in her job. If there are any questions please do not hesitate to contact us in the office.

The Grievant submitted a written request for accommodation to the Employer on March 11, 2014. in response to the question on the Employer's Request for Disability Accommodation form, what is the accommodation you are requesting, the Grievant answered: standard sit-down truck. Her request explained that the stand-up lift was causing her feet to go numb and there was pressure on her back, thighs and calves with her ankles swelling. Id. Not only did chiropractor Boutwell support this Request for Accommodation, she also went to Orthopedist Dr. Robert Gambrell who also recommended in writing on April 11, 2014, to the Employer that the Grievant be returned to the sit-down lift because the stand-up lift was causing her major medical problems. In this regard, Dr. Gambrell stated:

Tamela is under my care for low back pain. She has significant pain in her back and her left ankle causing her difficulties performing her job. She also has a history of a left ankle injury that has left her with arthritis in her ankle. Her back and her ankle feel better with rest… My recommendation would be that she return to her old type of forklift to be able to sit down. She should avoid prolonged standing at work…She could sit for 10-12 hours but should have relatively limited standing.

• The Grievant was out of work five-weeks from on or about March 21,2014, until on or about April 28,2014, due to problems with her back, feet and ankles. Both doctors clearly stated in writing to the Employer that the Grievant should be returned to the sit-down lift to perform her forklift job. Dr. Boutwell went on to state in writing on April 24, 2014, to the Employer that if the Grievant was required to operate the stand-up lift that she be given a fifteen-minute period each hour in which she did not drive. He also stated that he recommended no lifting over twenty-five pounds.

The Grievant submitted both Doctors' written statements and requests for accommodation to the Employer. On March 11, 2014, the Employer granted the request for fifteen-minute periods off of the lift each hour. However, it would not put her back on the sit-down lifts as recommended by both doctors. She was put back on the Clark 5500 stand-up lift contrary to the recommendation of the doctors. The doctors both made it clear that the solution to the Grievant's problems was to put her on the sit-down lift, but the Employer refused to honor the doctors and the Grievant's requests for accommodation associated with the sit-down lift.

As discussed above, the evidence established that all during this period in 2014 the Employer had three sit-down lifts being used at the plant to service the warehouse and it also had one sit-down lift that was a scissor lift which was in the area of the plant in which the Grievant worked. It is undisputed that the Grievant is and/or was the most senior forklift driver at the Augusta facility and she was in the same job dassificafion as the forklift drivers who serviced the warehouse who were using sit down lifts in the performance of their jobs. All of these jobs are within the same job dassificafion. The evidence is clear that if the Grievant had been given one of the sit-down forklifts to drive as requested by her and her doctors that no one would have been displaced. The only change that was needed was to provide her a sit-down lift to drive. She could have used this lift to perform her job duties as she had done for the past twenty-four years or she could have serviced the warehouse using the sit-down lifts. It is undisputed that she had performed the warehouse forklift work in the past and was fully qualified to do it Moreover, if the Employer was not willing to permit the Grievant to use one of the three sit-down lifts, it could have modified the scissor lift so she could perform her job on that lift. Further, it had the option to obtain another sit-down lift to accommodate the Grievant. The Employer did not exercise any of these options in an effort to accommodate her.

• On April 28, 2014, the Grievant returned to work from short term leave and as discussed above again began to drive the stand-up forklift. Thereafter, on May 23, 2014, she was examined by her family doctor, Dr. Danny Newman. According to the Grievant, Dr. Newman advised the Grievant that she was suffering from severe edema with swelling in her legs and ankle. Dr. Newman in writing recommended to the Employer that the Grievant be accommodated by moving her to a sit down forklift.

• On August 7, 2014, the Grievant again saw Dr. Newman. In writing, Doctor Newman advised the Employer that he recommended that she be moved to a sit-down forklift and that she could work the entire twelve-hour shift without restrictions if that accommodation was granted. He went on to state in writing that if the Grievant continued to be assigned to work on the stand-up lift that it would be necessary for her to have thirty-minutes each hour off of the standup lift in order to keep the edema in her legs from being a consistent problem.

The Grievant submitted the written request for accommodations prepared by Dr. Newman in writing to management on or about August 7, 2014. On September 26, 2014, the Grievant's request for accommodation was denied by the Employer. Management advised the Grievant in writing that her request to be accommodated by permitting her to use a sit-down forklift in the performance of her duties was denied. She was advised in writing that she could not work on the sit-down lift due to “safety and ergonomic” concerns. The evidence shows that the Employer's Corporate Human Resources Department concluded that the sit-down lifts were unsafe and should not be driven. According to the testimony of Dart's ADA/LOA Specialist, the Grievant's request for accommodation was denied because it was her understanding that the sit down lifts were unsafe and ergonomically unsuitable.

• On October 3, 2014, the Grievant was called into a meeting with management. The Grievant met with the local plant HR manager and her supervisor, the Regional HR manager, was on the phone for a conference call. During this meeting, management asked the Grievant if she had received any written communication from Dart concerning her doctor's requests for accommodation. The Grievant advised the management officials that she had not received anything in writing or in the mail relating to this most recent accommodation request. She was advised by them that she should go back to her doctor to see if he had any further recommendations as to her ability to work because her request for accommodations to be placed on the sit-down lift was denied.

According to the Grievant, during that meeting she requested not only to move to a sit-down lift but also to be moved to a packer job. Both of these requests for accommodation were denied. She also advised management that there was a sit-down lift that had been tagged and was sitting idle in the plant not being used and she was requesting to use that lift in the performance of her job. That request was also denied. According to the Grievant, the October 3, 2014, meeting ended with her being advised to go back to her doctor to see if he would change the restrictions which he had cited were required if she drove a stand-up lift.

The Grievant complied with management's request and met with Doctor Danny Newman. The Grievant advised Dr. Danny Newman of what management had stated to her and that she would not be placed on a sit-down lift to work. According to the Grievant, Dr. Newman advised her that he could not revise his restrictions as to what she could do if she worked on the stand-up lift.

• On October 10, 2014, management called the Grievant as previously arranged. During the conference call with the local HR manager and the regional HR manager, the Grievant advised the managers that her doctor would not revise his restrictions on her. She was then told she was being separated from her employment, and several days later received in the mail a Notice of Discharge which provided as the reason for separation “Unable to Return from Leave.”

body.p: The Grievant upon receiving the Notice of Discharge immediately contacted the Assistant Business Agent for Local 528 who in turn contacted the Employer's local HR manager and was advised by the HR manager that the Employer had asked the workers who were forklift drivers servicing the warehouse if any of them were willing to drive the stand-up lifts to accommodate the Grievant and none of these forklift drivers were willing to drive her stand-up lift. The Local's Assistant Business Agent was also advised that because none of these forklift drivers would agree to drive the stand-up lift that the Grievant and her doctors' requests for accommodation were denied. Here, testimony showed that the Union representative advised the HR manager that the Grievant was the most senior forklift driver at the Augusta Plant and that she should be assigned to the sit-down lift due to her seniority standing. He further advised that under Article 9, Section 4, of the collective bargaining agreement the Grievant should be able to bid down and/or laterally for a bona fide health reason or upon agreement of the parties. The Union representative further advised the HR manager that the Union was agreeing to the Grievant being assigned the sit-down lift and the Union had the authority to consent to such and not the workers. However, the HR manager refused to return the Grievant back to work and let the discharge stand.

The Union argues that in the present situation, the Employer and the Union agreed in Article 5 of the parties' collective bargaining agreement that the Employer can discharge a worker only for “just cause.” On this point, the Union points out that the term “just cause” is a broad term which does not have a precise definition and allows for consideration of a number of factors. Here, Arbitrator Jonathan Dworkin in Thermo King Corp. 102 LA 612, 614-615 (Dworkin 1993) dealt with the discharge of a worker under a “just cause” provision of a collective bargaining agreement wherein the Grievant was allegedly disabled and the union asserted that the employer could not discharge the grievant without attempting to make a reasonable accommodation for the Grievant's disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act. In discussing the “just cause” standard and how it should be applied in conjunction with the Americans with Disabilities Act, Arbitrator Dworkin wrote:

blockquote.p: When contract negotiators restrict an employer's disciplinary authority with the single term, “just cause,” they open each discipline grievance to arbitral intrusion. They license arbitrators to do precisely what the Supreme Court sought to restrain – fashioning decisions based on individual ideas of industrial justice. While the words “just cause” may seem straight forward and simple, they are not. They embody a profusion of concepts and ideals about what is a just penalty.

It is well settled that discipline is not just if it is manifestly unfair. But how does one decide what is “fair” and “unfair?” Where does one look for guidelines and principles? One source is arbitral “precedent” – the maxims set forth in nearly a half-century of published decisions on the subject. While the decisions are not carved in granite, they have been followed so long and so regularly as to create a presumption that negotiators intend to keep on following them when they agree that employees can be discharged only for just cause.

Another obvious resource for deciding what does or does not form just cause is basic societal values. The right of handicapped people to hold jobs they can perform was a societal value long before Congress made it a law. Arbitrators expressed it decades before ADA was enacted. Reasonable accommodation, the fundamental employer obligation under the Act, has long been recognized as an element of just cause by arbitrators. If anything, arbitrators have been more permissive than ADA.

The Arbitrator agrees that technically, he cannot decide whether Thermo King violated the Act when it discharged Grievant. That is a question for the courts. But he is empowered and obligated to decide if Grievant's penalty was just and fair. In making that determination, it is appropriate to look to the Act for guidance. Accordingly, it is held that the Union's ADA-based arguments are germane to this dispute. The Company's motion to dismiss them is denied.

body.p: Additionally, in the subject case, the Union argues the determination of whether the Employer had “just cause” to terminate the Grievant herein is closely intertwined with the question of whether the Employer improperly discriminated against her in violation of Article 27 of the CBA dealing with fair employment practices and equal opportunities. That Article in Section 1 states as follows:

blockquote.p: There shall be no discrimination by either the Company or the Union against any employee because of race, creed, color, age, sex, disability or national origin, in the administration and application of this Agreement.

body.p: In the CBA, therefore, the Union argues that the parties have expressly incorporated “disability discrimination.” The Union submits that the Americans with Disabilities Act and/or the principles in the ADA must be followed in deciding whether there has been “disability discrimination” and “just cause” for the discharge. These are standards that should be used by the Arbitrator in determining “just cause” and disability discrimination herein. This is consistent with the well-developed thrust of arbitral opinion. See e.g. Elkouri, How Arbitration Works, Sixth Edition at 816-817. In this regard, How Arbitration Works supra at 616-817 states as follows:

blockquote.p: Along these lines, a significant issue is the degree to which the rights of an employee with a disability are limited by the collective bargaining agreement. Another issue is how to apply the ADA in instances where the agreement specifically covers disabled employees but fails to specify what type of accommodations the employer must make. In one case, where the contract required an employer to place an employee who was Incapacitated for regular work due to non-work injury in “any work he can do,” the arbitrator held that the term must be interpreted in harmony with the ADA's requirement that the employer make “reasonable accommodations” for employees with physical limitations.

As the ADA has been developed further through litigation and interpretation by the courts and the EEOC, arbitral resolution of disability cases has undergone a sea change. Increasingly, arbitral decisions are informed by ADA case law, the statute's implementing regulations, EEOC guidelines, and parallel state laws.

Arbitrators have repeatedly held that employers must reasonably accommodate employees who have physical or mental impairments, and have looked to the ADA for guidance. The right to a reasonable accommodation has been found not only where the collective bargaining agreement expressly incorporates the ADA, or includes a nondiscrimination clause covering disability, but also under a general “just cause” provision. In one case, where the union had invoked the ADA and the employer raised defenses available under the Act, the arbitrator applied the ADA because the contract contained a nondiscrimination clause and a conflict of law provision.

body.p: According to the Union, Labor arbitrators have repeatedly applied the disability discrimination principles of the Americans with Disabilities Act in deciding whether “just cause” existed for discharge under a collective bargaining agreement. See South Peninsula Hospital, 120 LA 673, 679 (Landau 2004) (because the contract prohibits disability discrimination as defined by law, it is appropriate to apply the relevant legal principles from the ADA to determine whether there was just cause for the termination); GTE North, Inc., 113 LA 665, 672 (Brodsky 1999) (compliance with the ADA can be viewed as a component of just cause, a necessary element for discharge. Thermo King Corp., 102 LA 612, 615-616 (Dworkin 1993) (the concept of reasonable accommodation is an element of just cause for discharge); Meijer Inc., 103 LA 834, 838 (under a contract requiring just cause for disciplinary action against an employee, rights established by law, such as the ADA, must be taken into consideration in determining whether just cause exists.).

As discussed above, Article 27 of the parties' CBA provides that there shall be no discrimination… by the Company… against any employee because of disability. The Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. Section 12112(b) (5)
See Albertson's Inc. Case No. 95-26025 p. 20-21 (Miller 1996) (A) defines the term “discriminate” as follows:

blockquote.p: …not making reasonable accommodations to the known physical or mental limitations of an otherwise qualified individual with a disability who is an applicant or employee, unless such covered entity can demonstrate that the accommodation would impose an undue hardship on the operation of the business of such covered entity (Emphasis added)

body.p: To further support its case, the Union argues that:

Arbitrators have repeatedly held that such nondiscrimination provisions as that in Article 27 wherein the parties have agreed not to discriminate because of disability requires them to “reasonably accommodate” disabled employees and to comply with the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act. They hold that where a discharge is involved, that the consequence of a failure to reasonably accommodate a worker's disability is an unjust discharge. See Albertson's Inc., Case No. 95-26025 (Miller 1996) (where CBA provides that the Union and the Employer agree not to discriminate against any employee due to handicap and the ADA defines discrimination as not making reasonable accommodations, the Employer discriminated against the grievant by not reasonably accommodating his handicap). Sacred Heart Medical Center, (Tapp 2009) (because the Employer failed to accommodate the Grievant's disability and such conduct is prohibited by the nondiscrimination provision of the CBA and the Americans with Disabilities Act the termination of the Grievant was improper).

In the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals, which includes Georgia, the courts have held that to establish a claim of disability discrimination, a worker must prove three elements: (1) that he or she has a disability within the meaning of the Americans with Disabilities Act; (2) that with or without reasonable accommodations, he or she can perform the essential functions of the job he or she holds; and (3) that he or she was discriminated against because of his or her disability. Mazzeo v Color Resolutions International, 746 F. 3d 1264, 1367 (11th Cir. 2011?7); Holly v. Clairson Industries, LLC, 492 F. 3d 1247, 1256 (11th Cir. 2007); Jemigan v. Bellsouth Telecommunications, LLC, 17 F. Supp. 3d 1317, 1321 (N.D. Ga 2014).

Upon a showing by the worker that a reasonable accommodation exists, the burden shifts to the employer to prove that the worker's requested accommodation imposes an undue hardship. Jemigan supra at 1321.

The Americans with Disabilities Act defines the term “disability” as (1) a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of an individual's major life activities, (2) a record of such an impairment, or (3) being regarded as having such an impairment as described in subsection (1). Mazzeo v Color Resolutions International, 746 F. 3d 1264, 1268 (11th Cir. 2014); 42 U.S.C. Section 12102 (1). Under the Act as amended effective January 1, 2009
Congress made significant changes to the Americans with Disabilities Act by enacting the ADA Amendments Act of 2008 which became effective January 1, 2009. See Mazzeo at p. 1267. The amended Act applies to the Grievant's claims which all arose after January 1, 2009. Id. When Congress enacted the ADAAA, it indicated that one of the amendments purposes was to convey that the question of whether an individual's impairment is a disability should not demand extensive analysis. Id at 1262. Congress made clear that it was intent that earlier Supreme Court's interpretations of phrases defining what constitutes a disability such as substantially limits are overruled and the ADA is to be construed broadly in terms of extensive coverage and is not meant to be a demanding standard. Mazzeo at 1257, major life activities include but are not limited to….sleeping, walking, lifting….and bending.

Here, the Union points out that two doctors and a chiropractor who were and/or are the Grievant's treating physicians submitted statements to the Employer stating that the Grievant has major back and ankle problems and had a history of such impairments which impacted the Grievant's ability to work, stand and lift more than twenty-five pounds.
Dr. Boutwell stated that the Grievant had been a patient of ours since 2003 and that she has chronic tower back and left sacroiliac pain due to degenerative arthritic condition. Dr. Gambrell stated that the Grievant has a history of a left ankle injury that has left her with arthritis in her ankle. Dr. Newman stated the Grievant had bilateral lower extremity edema with venous insufficiency and chronic swelling which he described as a permanent long term condition. See Union exhibits U-17 through U-2424

Since the passage of the Amendments to the Americans with Disabilities Act in 2009 the courts have consistently found that workers with similar physical problems as that of the Grievant have a “disability” as contemplated by the Americans with Disabilities Act. See Mazzeo v Color Resolutions supra (plaintiff was disabled who had degenerative disc disease which included herniated disc and torn ligaments with 10 pound weight restriction); Cohen v CHLN Inc., 2011 WL 2713737 (E.D. Pa. 2011) 2011 WL 2713737 (E.D. Pa. 2011) (plaintiff who suffered from back and leg problems was disabled); Fleck v. WILMAC Corp. 2011 WL 1899198 (E.D. Pa. 2011) (the plaintiff who had a chronic ankle injury was disabled.).

The Grievant has been suffering from back and ankle problems since 2008 and she has constantly been under the care of the chiropractor. When she was required to stand twelve-hours operating the stand-up lift these conditions flared up and resulted in the standing and lifting limitations imposed by the doctors. Therefore, there is a clear record of evidence establishing that the Grievant has a disability within the meaning of the Americans with Disabilities Act. Moreover, she has been regarded as having such an impairment by the Employer because the Employer has in the past granted some of her requests for accommodation.

The Americans with Disabilities Act defines a “qualified individual” as an individual with a disability who, with or without, reasonable accommodation, can perform the essential functions of the employment position that such individual holds or desires. See Mazzeo at 1267, 1268 42 U.S.C. Section 1211(8). In this case, the evidence clearly establishes that the Grievant can perform the essential functions of the forklift job with reasonable accommodations. All three of her treating physicians stated in the documents that they submitted to the Employer that the Grievant can perform the forklift job so long as she is permitted to drive a sit down forklift.

In Holt v Olmsted Township Board of Trustees, 43 F. Supp. 2d 812, 823 (N.D. Ohio 1998) the court held that since the plaintiff had served twenty years in the job in question there was no dispute that she was qualified to perform the job. Here, the Grievant performed all aspects of the forklift job using the sit down lift for in excess of twenty-four years. There is and cannot be any dispute that she can perform all essential functions of the job if she is permitted to use the sit-down lift as recommended by her treating doctors.

The only real issue is whether the Employer should be required to keep in service a sit-down forklift as a reasonable accommodation to the Grievant or whether the Employer should have permitted the Grievant to perform the duties performed by warehouse forklift drivers instead of discharging her.

Although the Americans with Disabilities Act does not fully define “reasonable accommodation,” it does state that this concept includes the following: job restricting, part-time or modified work schedules, reassignment to a vacant position, acquisition or modification of equipment or devices, appropriate adjustment or modification of examination training materials or policies, the provision of qualified readers or interpreters, and other similar accommodations for individuals with disabilities. See Skerski v Time Warner Cable, 257 F. 3d 273, 284 (3rd Cir. 2001); 42 U.S.C. Section 12111(9)(B).

Both arbitrators and the courts have held that employers, as part of the reasonable accommodation obligation, must provide disabled workers special equipment and/or modified equipment to enable them to perform the essential functions of the job. See GTE North, 113 LA 1047, 1052 (Daniel 1999) (employer did not have just cause to discharge telephone technician, who had problems with leg and could not climb ladders where it could have accommodated that restriction by providing a bucket truck to the workers). Bartee v. Michelin North America Inc., 374 F. 3d 906 (10th Cir.) 2004 (although employer provided a cart to get around the plant, Plaintiff required a larger one); Skerski v Time Warner Cable Co., 257 F. 3d 273, 285-286 (3d. Cir. 2001) (employee whose panic disorder prevented climbing might have been accommodated by the use of bucket truck). Shannon v. Verizon New York Inc., 519 F. Supp. 2d 304, 309 (N.D.N.Y. 2007) (disabled plaintiff able to perform job of field technician which has 100 pound weight requirement through the use of bucket truck); Jackanin v Mount Sinai Hospital, 2003 WL 402443 (S.D.N.Y. 2003) (factual dispute existed as to whether employer failed to reasonably accommodate disabled workers by providing adaptive computer equipment); Fol v City of New York, 2003 WL 21556938 at 8 (S.D.N.Y 2003) (factual issue for jury existed whether employer accommodate disabled employee's request to have ergonomic work station).

In the present case, the evidence is clear that the Grievant and her coworkers had been driving sit-down lifts for some twenty-four years. The Employer, however, decided to do away with the sit-down lifts and to use stand-up lifts because they were viewed as safer and more ergonomic. The Union submits, however, that even though the Employer decided to go to stand-up lifts it was under a duty to reasonably accommodate the Grievant and her doctors' requests that she be given a sit-down lift to perform her duties.

There is no question that if the Employer had honored the Grievant and her doctor's accommodation requests that she could have performed ail the essential functions of the forklift job. Indeed, the fact that this work had been performed for the previous twenty plus years with the drivers using sit-down lifts is proof positive that all aspects of the forklift job could be done on a sit-down lift. The Grievant's doctors made it very clear in their statements to the Employer that if the Grievant was assigned to a sit-down lift that she would not need any further accommodation in performing her job.

In the present situation, there are a number of ways that the Employer could have accommodated the Grievant and her doctors' requests for this reasonable accommodation. If it did not have a sit-down lift, then it could have rented one. The cited cases show that employers have been required to make such expenditures to accommodate disabled workers. The evidence shows, however, that the Employer did have sit-down lifts at the time of the Grievants discharge. At least three such lifts were being driven by forklift drivers who serviced the warehouse. There was a sit-down lift that was taken out of service and could have been repaired. Moreover, the Employer had a sit-down scissor lift available at the time of the Grievant's discharge which was used to move rolls of paper.

Upon a showing by a disabled worker that a reasonable accommodation exists, the burden shifts to the employer to prove the worker's requested accommodation imposes an “undue hardship.” Jemigan v Bellsouth Communications, 17 F. Supp. 3d 1317, 1321 (N.D.Ga 2014). The ADA defines “undue hardship” as “an action requiring significant difficulty or expense in light of various factors set forth in 42 U.S.C. Section 12111 (10)(B). These factors essentially include the nature and cost of the accommodation, the size and financial resources of the covered entity, and the impact of the accommodation on the operation of the facility, including the impact of the ability of other employees to perform their duties and the impact on the facility's ability to conduct business.

Determining undue hardship “requires a fact-specific, individualized inquiry. Nunes v Walmart Stores, 164 F. 3d 1243, 1247 (9th Cir. 1999). It requires “concrete evidence.” Morton v United Parcel Service, 272 F. 3d 1249, 156-157 (9th Cir. 2001). Assumptions or opinions are not sufficient to establish undue hardship. Anderson v General Dynamics, 589 F. 2d 397, 402 (9th Cir. 1979) (religious discrimination).

In the present case, Dart's Corporate, LOA/ADA Specialist ultimately made the decision as to whether or not the Grievant's request to be accommodated by permitting her to drive a sit-down forklift should be granted. According to the evidence the Grievant's request for accommodation was denied not because of any economic reason but because it was the LOA/ADA Specialist's understanding that it was unsafe to use the sit-down lift. The Company's September 26, 2004, letter to the Grievant denying her request to perform her job on a sit-down lift cited “due to safety and ergonomic concerns” as the basis for the accommodation denial.

The evidence clearly shows that this corporate representative based her decision and conclusion that it was unsafe to use the sit-down lift on unfounded assumption and speculation. Cross examination at the Arbitration hearing revealed the LOA/ADA Specialist believed that it was unsafe to continue to use the sit-down lift in the Augusta plant, yet she could not give any specific facts to support this conclusion. Indeed, she admitted that she was unaware of whether or not there had been any OSHA reportable accidents at the Augusta plant associated with the use of sit-down lifts; and, she was not aware of the significant problems with safety associated with the stand-up lifts.

The Union put into evidence instance after instance in which fork lift drivers had been seriously injured driving stand-up lifts similar to and/or exactly the same as the Clark 5500 lifts in operation by the Employer at the Augusta plant.
See Union exhibit U-1 Additionally, the Union offered evidence and expert testimony explaining why sit-down lifts were much safer than stand-up lifts; and that no one had been injured driving a sit-down lift at the Augusta plant which was of such nature to constitute an OSHA reportable accident.

In rebutial, the Employer offered little clear evidence to justify its assertion that the sit-down lifts were unsafe. The only forklifts shown to be unsafe at this plant are the stand-up lifts put into operation in 2014. Indeed, not only do the numerous lawsuits over this type of stand-up lift show how unsafe these lifts are, the evidence shows that a number of workers have experienced significant discomfort and physical problems due to the stand-up lifts since they have been put into operation at the Augusta Plant. In addition to the Grievant's testimony another long-term forklift operator also testified in detail concerning the severe physical problems suffered when using the Clark 5500 stand-up lifts; and, both testified that that they were aware of coworkers who had similar problems.

The Employer argues that the Plant Manager thoroughly investigated the stand-up lifts and in good faith determined that they were safer that sit-down lifts. The Plant Manager testified that he reviewed the OSHA website during his investigation. However, that review failed to notice that OSHA had posted on its website a warning concerning stand-up lifts and how forklift drivers have been severely injured when they back into low hanging stationary objects while driving standup-lifts.
See Union exhibit U-3… a Safety and Health information Bulletin dated July 27, 2009 entitled Standup Forklift under-ride Hazards. That Internet posting states that one of the potential hazards faced by standup. Forklift operators is the crushing hazard that can arise when traveling in a standup lift to a facility where there are horizontal racks or beams. Moreover, the Plant Manager testified that he was unaware that any lawsuits had been filed against the manufacturer of the Crown stand-up forklift in question due to the design flaws in these lifts and the injuries forklift drivers have had while driving the forklifts. These lawsuits go back more than a decade and information relating to them is readily available on the internet.

The Employer bore the burden of proof to show that the accommodation sought by the Grievant caused an undue hardship. The Union submits that it absolutely failed to meet its burden. Indeed, the overwhelming evidence is that if any lifts were shown to be unsafe herein they were the Crown 5500 stand-up lifts, not the sit-down lifts.

It is the Union's position that the Employer even if it did not have a sit-down lift available for the Grievant to drive was required to lease and/or purchase this equipment in order to accommodate the Grievant's disability. The Union cited a number of cases where employers have been required to obtain, purchase or lease the necessary equipment to accommodate a disabled worker's needs and request for accommodation. Moreover, as the evidence clearly shows, that at the time of the Grievant's discharge the Employer had three sit-down lifts which were driven by the forklift drivers who worked in the warehouse section of the plant.

The evidence clearly shows that the Grievant was the most senior forklift driver in the plant and she had more seniority than these three warehouse forklift drivers. The Grievant requested that she be assigned to one of these forklifts and/or the warehouse forklift jobs. Here, the Employer, instead of talking with the Union concerning this accommodation request, went to the three forklift drivers who serviced the warehouse and asked them if they were willing to permit the Grievant to drive their assigned sit-down lifts and/or to perform their assigned duties.

On this point, the Union submits that the Employer was legally required to bargain over these matters with it and not the workers in question. See Paul Mueller Company, 332 NLRB 332 (2000) (supervisors polling employees as to their preferences as to their schedules unlawful direct dealing in violation of 8(a)5 of NLRA because employer never consulted with Union about proposed changes or asked its permission to discuss matters directly with employees); The Detroit Edison Company, 370 NLRB 564 (employer's distribution of memo to employees seeking to ascertain the employee's personal preference about the work station each employee wished to be assigned unlawful, since action constituted direct dealing):

The ADA in 42 U.S.C. Section 12111(9)(8) provides in part…the term reasonable accommodation may include job restructuring, part time or modified work schedules, reassignment to a vacant position, acquisition or modification of equipment or devices. Here, the Grievant was the most senior forklift driver. She requested to be given a sit down lift to perform her normal duties and/or to be moved to performing her duties in the warehouse so she could use a sit down lift. Technically, she was not seeking a reassignment to another position. Rather, she was asking the Employer to restructure her job. The restructuring would permit her job to be performed using a sit-down lift as opposed to a stand-up lift. This type of accommodation falls clearly within the definition of a reasonable accommodation under the ADA.

Alternatively, she was seeking to be moved to the warehouse to perform the warehouse function of the forklift driver position. Arbitrator Richard L. Kanner in City of Deabom Heights, 101 LA 809, 815 (Kanner 1993) held that where a Police Lieutenant with a disability sought to move from midnight to day shifts to accommodate his disability that such action involved a “job restructuring” and not a reassignment to another position. The basis for this conclusion was that since this Police Lieutenant remained a Lieutenant after the job restructuring he was not reassigned to another position but rather to another shift.

There is nothing in the parties' CBA which prohibits the Employer from moving a worker from one location to another. The Grievant was not seeking to be reassigned to another position or job. She was seeking to remain a forklift driver but to perform her forklift job in the warehouse. All the forklift drivers worked together as a crew. Some workers servicing the plant production; some serviced the warehouse.

The Union submits that the compelling evidence shows that the Grievant has a disability as defined by the Americans with Disability Act; she was qualified for the forklift job with reasonable accommodation. The evidence is also clear that but for the denial of the reasonable accommodation of permitting the Grievant to use a sit-down forklift to perform her job that she would not have been discharged. Moreover, the Employer failed to prove that the requested accommodation would result in “undue hardship.” Thus, the Union has proven discrimination against the Grievant due to her disability and unjust discharge. Therefore, the Union submits that the Arbitrator should sustain the grievance.

The Union submits that the Arbitrator should order the Employer to reinstate the Grievant with full back pay, seniority and benefits to her former position of forklift driver and require the Employer to accommodate her disability by providing her a sit-down forklift to drive in the performance of her job.

The Union contends the discharge herein cannot stand. The Grievant was unjustly discharged. The Union requests that the Arbitrator sustain the grievance based on the conditions specified above. Finally, the Union asks the Arbitrator to retain jurisdiction over this matter if there is any dispute as to remedy.

The parties were unable to fully agree on the issue(s) to be addressed by the Arbitrator. Accordingly, it was agreed that each party, in its post-hearing brief, would submit its suggested statement of the issue or issues and the Arbitrator would then frame the issue(s) to be addressed.
