h4.b: V. SUMMARY OF THE EVIDENCE, DISCUSSION, ANALYSIS, AND FINDINGS

body.p:
The record of the matter before the Arbitrator consists of the swom testimony of seven witnesses examined by the parties' Counsels and the Arbitrator during a hearing conducted April 22, 2015; and some one-thousand, one-hundred, and fifty-eight (1,158) pages of documentation offered and accepted while the hearing record was open, which was comprised of twelve (12) Arbitrator/Joint exhibits, eight (8) Company/Employer exhibits, and eighteen (18) Union/Grievant exhibits.
Arbitrators exercising their own authority may request any additional documentation and information they have a reasonable basis to believe is germane to the case [See Eikouri & Elkouri, How Arbitration Works 6th Ed Ch.83.D p353]. Often in the arbitration process matters are assumed or accepted without discussion or citation of authority, in that arbitrators often use arbitral notice; nevertheless, this Arbitrator, like other finders of facts, cannot ignore all of his prior teaming and experience, as explained in Converters Ink, 68 LA 593 (Sembower 1977), that is what the parties take into account when they complement him with their mutual selection as arbitrator.

This matter is before the Arbitrator on appeal by the Union under the provisions of Article 11 of the parties' CBA. As explained above, on October 16, 2014, Ms. Tamela Wells filed a formal grievance under the provisions of Article 10 of the parties' CBA over her separation from employment as a forklift operator at Dart Container Corporation, Solo Cup Operating facility in Augusta, Georgia. The grievance cited violation of Articles 9 and 10 of the parties' CBA, and provided among other things that the Company did not have just cause to terminate the Grievant. During the pre-hearing administrative conference the parties stipulated that the matter was properly before the Arbitrator and that there were no arbitrability questions.
In response to the Arbitrator's request for a copy for the complete grievance file, the only document provided was the completed IBT Local 528 Grievance Report Form completed by Ms. Wells and filed October 16, 2014 showing receipt by management the same day. The parties' CBA, Article 10 provides for a three-step procedure. However, the grievance form does not provide documentation of the three-step process. Testimony provided that there was some sort of a meeting/hearing held on the grievance. However, neither management nor the Union provided any further documentation of the grievance procedure and both Counsels told the Arbitrator that what had been provided was all that there was. Accordingly, they confirmed/stipulated that the matter was properly before the Arbitrator and that there were no arbitrability issues, procedural or substantive.

In May 2012, Dart Container Corporation acquired the Solo Cup Company and its manufacturing facility in Augusta, Georgia. For a number of years, prior to being acquired, the Solo Cup Company's Augusta facility leased sit-down style forklifts; and, these leased vehicles continued in operation after Dart Container purchased Solo Cup Company and its facility. Subsequently, with the leases on the sit-down forklifts about to expire, management at the Augusta facility decided not to renew the equipment leases and to purchase new stand-up style forklifts. The matter before the Arbitrator stims from the Company's decision to replace leased sit-down forklifts in use at its Augusta, Georgia facility with purchased stand-up forklifts.

The evidence shows in 2013 the Augusta Plant Manager was charged with the responsibility of replacing the leased forklifts used in the facility with purchased forklifts. Accordingly, in keeping with the Company's safety-focused culture, the Plant Manager, in conjunction with the facility's safety experts, investigated the best forklift options for the facility. After considering data about the history of forklift-related accidents and injuries in the facility, the physical configuration of the workspace in the facility, OSHA ergonomic guidance, and research related to the ergonomic benefits of a stand-up style forklift, the decision was made to replace the teased, sit-down style forklifts with stand-up style forklifts. These new stand-up forklifts were delivered in early February 2014
The evidence shows that the Company was leasing eight Yale manufacture sit-down forklifts model number ERC045VG with a weight/capacity of 4,500 pounds. Five of these Yale sit-down lifts were dropped from service on March 17, 2014 and returned to the vendor. Two other Yale sit-down lifts were removed from service and returned to the vendor on December 19, 2014; and one Yale sit-down lift was removed from service when its service contract expired on August 11, 2014, but was not removed from the facility and sent back to the vendor until January 5, 2015. These eight Yale lifts were replaced by five new Crown stand-up forklifts model number RC55330-30-180TT with a weight/capacity of 3,000 pounds were delivered to the facility in early February 2014; and two Yale stand-up lifts model ESCO4OACN with weight/capacity of 4,000 pounds were delivered December 10, 2014. Finally, the eight replacement lift was a Toyota sit-down carton/clamp forklift model number BFBCHU25 with a weight/capacity of 5,000 pounds which is owned by Dart and was moved to Augusta from another facility.; and shortly thereafter the Company provided training and driver certification for all its Augusta facility forklift operators.
The record shows that training/certification was provided to 30+ individuals during the period March 5-7, 2014, and additional employees were trained/certified on April 10, 2014. The Plant Manager testified that he briefed the employees on the new equipment
See Employer exhibit, E-1., and, that after the training they maintained both sit-down and stand-up lifts during a transition period through March to give the operators an opportunity to become acquainted with the new lifts. Then in early April the sit-down lifts “went away.’

As thoroughly outlined above, shortly after the introduction of the new Crown model RC5530 stand-up forklifts, the training and certification of the forklift operators, and the transition from use of the sit-down lifts to full time use of the stand-up lifts; in March 2014, the Grievant started experiencing back, leg, and ankle pain; complained about the problems and requested a leave of absence: and, submitted her initial request that she be allowed to use a sit-down style forklift as a disability accommodation when she returned to work.

Here the Company assigned a, Leave of Absence/Americans with Disabilities Act Specialist (LOA/ADA Specialist) in the corporate office to review and respond to Grievant's request. Following internal procedures, the assigned LOA/ADA Specialist reviewed the Grievant's request – Including the Grievant's preferred accommodation, a return to using a sit-down style forklift; as well as, the alternative accommodation of working for fifteen minutes off of the forklift for every hour spent working on the forklift. Based on the return to work restrictions from the Grievant's medical doctors, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist determined that: (1) Ms. Wells had a Qualifying disability that limits a major life function; (2) she was qualified to perform the essential functions of her position; (3) it could approve and provide the alternate accommodation suggested by Ms. Wells' doctors, of working for fifteen minutes off of the forklift for every hour spent working on the forklift; and (4) it would implemented the approved accommodation upon the Grievant's return to work on May 2, 2014. The Grievant's preferred accommodation — a return to the old-style sit-down forklift was not accepted/approved because the LOA/ADA Specialist determined it would impede the facility's ability to realize the important ergonomic and safety gains sought in the switch to stand-up forklifts.
See Employer exhibits E-5 and E-6, and Union exhibits U-9, U-10U-11, U-12, and U-13.

About a month after returning to work on her regular twelve-hour schedule, and working in accordance with the approved accommodation, on May 23, 2014, the Grievant went to her primary care physician for her annual physical.
This physical was for personal reasons and not required by the Company. During this examination her doctor inquired about the swelling in her legs and ankles, and Ms. Wells explained her work situation. As a result of his examination, the primary care physician provided Ms. Wells a written statement explaining the results of his examination and recommending that the Grievant not be required to stand all day long and allowed to return to operating a sit-down forklift.
See Union exhibit, U-15. On June 24, 2014, the Grievant provided the Company her primary care physician's May 23rd written statement explaining her medical condition and the physician's opinion that it “…would be better if the patient did not have to stand all day long” and again suggesting a return to a sit-down forklift.

Accepting this May 23rd written statement as a new accommodation request, the Company's LOA/ADA Specialist sent a letter to the Grievant the same day, June 24, 2014, requesting further information. According to the Company, the Grievant failed to acknowledge or respond to the June 24th request. So after thirty-days passed with no communication from the Grievant, on July 25, 2014, the LOA/ADA Specialist sent a letter informing the Grievant that the request was being closed based on the Grievant stalling the interactive process, but that she could restart the process at any time by submitting the requested information.
See Employer exhibits, E-7 and E-8.

On August 7, 2014, the Grievant went back to see her primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. On this visit the doctor gave Ms. Wells a second letter providing that she could not stand for more than one hour without being able to be seated for thirty minutes, and again recommending that she be able to return to a sit-down forklift.
See Union exhibit, U-16. Here the record shows that the Grievant provided this second letter to the local Human Resources (HR) manager on or about August 18, 2014.

Almost a month and a half later, when the Grievant reported to work the meaning of October 3, 2014, she was instructed to report to the facilities' personnel office. Upon arriving at the personnel office, the local HR manager asked Ms. Wells if she had received a letter in September from Dart Container. After responding that she had not received any letter from Dart, the local HR manager explained that Ms. Well's request for further accommodation was denied. The local HR manager then called her regional HR manager and the two HR managers and Grievant had a three-way discussion about the Grievant's situation. This discussion concluded with the Grievant being told to “go home, go back to see her doctor(s) to see if there were any other accommodations that could be suggested;” and, that they [the local HR manager, the regional HR manager, and the Grievant] would have another conversation on October 10th.

Upon returning to her residence, in the daily mail delivery, the Grievant received the letter from Dart that the local HR manager had discussed with her. That letter, dated, September 26, 2014, provided in part:

blockquote.p: On 8/18/14 you submitted medical documentation requesting the following disability accommodation:

li.p: To use a sit-down type of forklift.
To work from a seated position for at least 30 minutes after each hour worked in a standing position.
Frequent breaks to keep your legs elevated.

blockquote.p: After reviewing your request and engaging in an interactive dialogue, unfortunately, we find we must deny your request for the following reasons:

1. Due to the safety and ergonomic concerns encountered with the sit-down type of forklifts a safety-based decision was previously made to eliminate them from the plant by the end of 2014. There currently are 2-3 sit-down type of forklifts remaining in the distribution center which will also be eliminated by the end of the year for safety reasons. Despite the pending elimination of said forklifts deemed to be less safe, we still made inquiries of employees in those positions as to whether they might voluntarily exchange positions with you. We found no employees willing to make the exchange. Therefore, a sit-down type of forklift is not available.

2. After reviewing your current job functions, there are not a sufficient number of duties that can be done from a seated position to fill 30 minutes after each 1 hour worked standing on your feet. The ability to stand regularly (up to 67-100% of the time) is an essential function of your job. Under the ADA a “qualified individual” is a person who is able to perform all of the essential functions of the job with or without accommodation.
3. At this time there are no open positions for which you are qualified, nor are we aware of any such positions opening in the foreseeable future.

We believe we have made every effort to provide reasonable accommodation as requested and have exhausted all possibilities. Consequently, at this time we believe you are unable to perform the essential functions of your position with or without reasonable accommodation.

While we have made every effort to include you in the accommodation process it is possible that you have additional information that you feel we should consider. If so please present this additional information to your HR representative for review…”

body.p: On October 10, 2014, the local HR and regional HR managers called the Grievant. The regional HR manager asked Ms. Wells if she had been back to see her doctor. Ms. Wells said she had. The regional HR manager then asked if there were any changes or any restrictions lifted. The Grievant responded that there were no changes in her medical condition and the restriction continued as previously explained by her doctor. The regional HR manager then told Ms. Wells, “since [her] doctor didn't lift [her] restrictions that they [the Company] did not have a job for [her then] or in the future…” and said good bye.

The Union's primary argument in this appeal is that the separation of the Grievant from her employment, her discharge, was not for just cause, as required by Article 5 of the parties' CBA, because the Grievant was discriminated against in violation of Article 27 of the parties' CBA, in that the Company did not provide a reasonable accommodation as required by the ADA.

While acknowledging that the Company had the right under the CBA to change the equipment used in the facility, that is, to move from using sit-down forklifts to using stand-up forklifts; the Union argues that because the Company failed to accommodate the Grievant's request, as stipulated by her physicians, to be allowed to use a sit-down forklift, which would have all-but eliminated her medical problems, it discriminated against the Grievant both under the ADA and the CBA.

While identifying Article 5 of the CBA as one of the relevant provisions of the contract, the Company has expressed no specific position on the just cause provision; its justification for, and defense of, the action separating the Grievant from her employment boils down to arguments that the Company(‘s):

li.p: had every right under Article 5 of the CBA to change the equipment used at the facility from sit-down type forklifts to stand-up type forklifts;
management exercised good-faith decision making in selecting the new stand-up forklifts for use at the Augusta facility by appropriately:
reviewing and considering the facility's safety, health, and accident record;
researching the safety, ergonomic, and operational factors of the different types of forklifts available on the market; and
determining that stand-up style forklifts offered a safer and better operational fit for the Augusta facility;
did not discriminate against the Grievant in violation of Article 27 of the CBA because it acted appropriately and within the provisions of the ADA, in that:
after being made aware of the Grievant's medical problems, it worked with, and engaged the Grievant in an interactive dialogue, to identify and offer accommodation;

for the first request for accommodation, it found that the Grievant had a qualifying disability, was qualified to perform the essential functions of her position with accommodation; and, accepted/approved/apply the alternate accommodation recommended by her doctors (e.g., while operating a stand-up forklift, being allowed to work off the lift for fifteen minutes after every hour on the lift); and

for the second request for accommodation, while determining that the two possible accommodations recommended by the Grievant's physicians were not reasonable (e.g., being allowed to return to using a sit-down lift which management had determined to be less safe than the stand-up lifts; and being allowed to be off her feet for thirty-minutes, sitting with her feet elevated, after every hour standing while operating the stand-up lift, because review of the Grievant's current job functions found that there were not a sufficient number of duties that could be done from a seated position to fill thirty-minutes after each hour worked standing on your feet) continued the interactive process in an attempt to identify a reasonable accommodation. Therefore…

had no choice but to separate the Grievant from her employment since her medical conditions had not changed; she and her doctors were not able to offer any other accommodations, therefore the collaborative and interactive process halted; and, since she could not continue to perform the essential functions of her job with or without accommodation. And, therefore,
had just cause to separate the Grievant.

body.p: The Union argues that in the present situation, it and the Employer agreed in their collective bargaining agreement that the Employer must have “just cause” for discharging or separating an employee from employment. This agreement is documented in Article 5, the Management Right's clause which provides in part “Except as expressly modified by the specific provisions of the Agreement, and subject to the grievance and arbitration procedure provided herein, the Company also has the right to promote, suspend, demote, discipline or discharge for just cause or transfer employees.” As the Company has not disputed the Union's position, the Arbitrator finds that the separation of the Grievant from her employment (her discharge) must have been for just cause.

As pointed out by the Union the term “just cause” does not have a precise definition, and Arbitrators are usually required to consider different factors when defining and applying the term in different situations. Even though the parties' CBA does not define the term “just cause,” in this case, the parties, and their agreement, authorize the Arbitrator to hear and determine the issue(s). While an Arbitrator cannot “add to, detract from, alter or otherwise amend in any way the provisions of the Agreement”; by selecting the undersigned to hear and determine the issue(s) the parties are asking him to give meaning to the term “just cause,” and to draw upon his knowledge, experience, wisdom, and appropriate references to fairly decide the matter. Therefore, what constitutes “just cause” is a question the Arbitrator is to decide.

The elements or factors that need to be considered when giving meaning to the term “just cause,” vary depending on the action taken by the employer. Where as in this case, the CBA has a clear “cause” provision, with or without a delineating adjective like “just” or “sufficient,” that provision includes a number of substantive and procedural elements. Primary among its substantive elements is the requirement that enough proof exists that the employee engaged in the conduct for which he or she was discharged. For example, where an employee's actions or conduct result in discharge being a form of discipline, like most other Arbitrators, the undersigned usually applies some form of Daugherty's “seven tests” in determining whether or not the elements of “cause” have been met.
Koven, Adolph M. And Susan L. Smith Just Cause: The Seven Tests Page 10, Colorace Publications Inc., San Francisco, CA 1985; See also Discipline and Discharge in Arbitration (Norman Brand Ed. 1998). Courts and commentators cite numerous sources for the Daughterty test, including Grief Bros. Cooperage Corp (1964), 42 LA 555 and Whirlpool Corp. (1972) 58 LA 421. Whatever its exact origins, and regardless of whether the concept is labeled good cause, just cause, or some other similar term, there is no dispute that the seven tests were established and refined by Daugherty and that they have been used routinely for over 30 years For, non-disciplinary separations, other elements or factors need to be considered.

In the case at-hand, the parties' agreement also has a general “fair employment practices and equal opportunity” clause, Article 27, which prohibits the Employer, as well as the Union, from discriminating against any employee based on various factors including disability. Here, citing Thermo King Corporation, the Union points to Arbitrator Dworkin's decision/award
102 LA 612, 614-615 (Dworkin 1993) as discussed offered in the Union's post-hearing brief. considering of a just cause provision where, as with the subject case, the Grievant alleged and the Union asserted that the Employer could not discharge the Grievant without attempting to make a reasonable accommodation for the Grievant's disability under the provisions of the ADA. While other arbitration decisions/awards, published or not, are not binding, every Arbitrator weighs the value of such cited dedsions/awards based on the similarity of the terms and situation addressed to the facts presented in the case at hand.

Both parties point to Article 27 of their CBA as relevant, the Union has argued that the provisions and principles of the ADA should be followed in determining “just cause;” and, the Company has not refuted that position. Accordingly, the undersigned concurs with the Union's position that the provisions and principles of the ADA should be followed and considered in determining if the Employer had “just cause” to separate the Grievant. Clearly, the weight of arbitral opinion since the enactment of the ADA has been to apply the ADA in instances where the agreement specifically covers disabilities but fails to address accommodations.

The ADA provides that “[n]o covered entity shall discriminate against a qualified individual with a disability because of that disability…” in regard to various aspects of employment inducing…discharge.
42 U.S.C. §12112(a) In addition, the ADA provides that the term “discriminate” includes:

blockquote.p: “…not making reasonable accommodation to the known physical or mental limitations of an otherwise qualified individual with a disability…unless [it] can demonstrate that the accommodation would impose an undue hardship on the operation of [its] business….” [Emphasis added]

body.p:
Here, the Employer has the burden to prove “just cause” for the discharge; the Union has the burden to prove discrimination; the applicable quantum of proof is a preponderance of the evidence.
As provided in Elkouri & Elkouri, How Arbitration Works at 948-950 (6th Ed. 2003) Most arbitrators apply the preponderance of the evidence standard to ordinary discipline and discharge cases.
Accordingly, to prove discrimination by sustaining its claim of failure to provide reasonable accommodations, the Union must prove that:

li.p: the Grievant has a disability, as defined by the ADA;
despite her disability, she was qualified for the position held, with or without reasonable accommodation; and
if accommodation was required, she was denied a reasonable accommodation.

body.p: The ADA defines the term “disability” as:

li.p: A physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of an individual's major life activities;
A record of such an impairment; or
Being regarded as having such an impairment as described in subsection 1.

body.p: In the case at hand, the evidence clearly shows that: (1) three different medical providers, the Grievant's chiropractor, orthopedist, and primary care physician, found that she suffered back and ankle problems, had a history of such impairments, and that recent work conditions exacerbated the problems manifesting in increased swelling in the legs, venous insufficiency and edema; and, (2) the Company concurred and found the Grievant had a disability as defined by the ADA. Furthermore, the Company's actions after making its initial determination that the Grievant had a covered disability showed it continued to regarded her as having such a disability. Accordingly, as to the first prong of the inquiry, the Arbitrator finds the Grievant, Ms. Wells, had and continues to have a disability as defined by the ADA.

As for whether or not the Grievant, despite her disability, was or is qualified for the position she held, with or without accommodation — The ADA defines a “qualified individual” as an individual with a disability who, with or without, reasonable accommodation, can perform the essential functions of the employment position that individual held or desired. Here, the Grievant performed all aspects of her position as a forklift operator at the Dart/Solo Augusta facility for some twenty-four years until the equipment she was required to operate was changed from a sit-down style lift to a stand-up style lift; and, could continue performing the essential functions of her job with reasonable accommodation. There can be no question that the Grievant, prior to the introduction of the stand-up forklift, was qualified to perform all aspects, induding the essential functions, of the position of forklift operator. Furthermore, the Company, in addressing the Grievant's initial request for accommodation, found that she met the ADA definition of a “qualified individual” because she could perform the essential functions of her job, with or without accommodation, when it approved the initial request granted, and applied the accommodation of fifteen minutes off the stand-up lift for every hour on the lift. However, in denying her second request the Company determined she was not a “qualified individual” because she could not perform the essential functions of her job without accommodation.

As to the essential functions of the position the Grievant held and desired, the Company argues that there are two different forklift jobs, each located in a different “department” and having its on position description
The Union argues that all forklift operators In the August facility are the same and perform the same, perform the same duties and functions, and that the CBA does not make any distinctions between forklift operators…The Company addressed this issue in its post-hearing brief under the title of Factual Inaccuracles arguing that there were two different forklift positions and that the duties and essential functions differ, and provided copies of both position descriptions. The Company provided copies of two position descriptions (PDs), one with the title forklift operator, the other with the title receiving power truck operator. The first PD (forklift operator) provides that the essential duties and responsibilites are:
Service various production departments with packaging materials and raw materials.
Read scheduled, accurately record movement of packaging materials on movement sheets, using addition, subtraction, multitiplication, and division.
Operate carousel, assist in clearing conveyer jams, palletize cases, wrap pallets, baler, trash compactor, and run production tickets.
The second PD (receiving power truck operator located in the warehouse) provides that the essential duties and responsibilities are:
Unload inbound trucks.
Check in material, i.e., count items damage.
Stores material in assigned areas.
Delivers materials to manufacturing and spare parts.
In addition both PCs provide a general job summary. The two PDs describe different job requirements (education, work experience, certificates, skills) but provide the same physical requirements (except for vision requirements which differ between the two PDs), woridng conditions, etc. The first PD (forklift operator was last revised June 13, 2012; the second PD (receiving power truck operator) was last revised June 3, 2008. Review of the two position descriptions (PDs) shows that one (titled receiving power truck operator) last revised in 2008, covers positions located in the warehouse only, and has different essential duties and responsibilities than; the second PD (titled forklift operator) last revised in 2012 and covering positions servicing “various departments.” It is noted, however, that neither PD describes the “primary” function or duty of an employee assigned to perform the described work, that is, “to drive/operate a forklift.” Clearly the more recent PD, the one for forklift operator, appears to be the more inclusive. Finally, each PD has a provision providing that “The physical demands described…are representative of those that must be met by the employee to successfully perform the essential functions of the job. [And that] Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.”

Based on the evidence available, as to the second prong of the inquiry, the Arbitrator finds, as the Company found regarding the Grievant's initial request for accommodation, that the Grievant, Ms. Wells, did and does meet the ADA definition of a “qualified individual.”

The only reason the Company found that the Grievant did not meet the definition of a “qualified individual” in reviewing and deciding her second request for accommodation, was that it denied the accommodations requested. So to decide this matter it is necessary to review the Company's decisions in the second request.

Clearly, the genesis of the Grievant's separation/discharge was management's decision to change the forklifts used at the Augusta facility from a sit-down type to a stand-up type. The Grievant had worked numerous years using a sit-down forklift without suffering the medical problems that manifested in a short period of time after being required to switch from the sit-down lift to a stand-up lift. Furthermore, after each of the Grievant's three different medical providers, a chiropractor, orthopedist, and her primary care physician, examined her, all attributed her medical problems to prolonged standing in the almost stationary position required to operate the stand-up forklift over an extended twelve-hour shift. And, while suggesting an alternative accommodation, all recommended that allowing the Grievant to return to using a sit-down forklift was preferred since it would not just lessen her medical problems, but would most likely eliminate them.

Much has been presented and argued regarding the Company's decision to change from the use of sit-down forklifts to stand-up forklifts. Here the Arbitrator agrees with the Company, as basically stipulated to be the Union at the hearing and in its briefs that management did and does have the right under the provisions of Article 5, of the CBA, to “change or eliminate existing methods of operations, equipment or facilities….” This provision clearly provides that management had the right, for whatever reason, to move from the use of leased sit-down forklifts to the use of self-owned stand-up forklifts. Furthermore, the Arbitrator does not doubt that the Augusta Plant manager did attempt to conduct some review and investigation to determine the product he felt would best meet the Company's needs in Augusta. And, while the compact design of the selected stand-up forklift, may have been determined as better suited to a workspace like the Augusta facility; whether or not the newly purchased stand-up forklift is safer than the previously leased sit-down forklift requires more evidence than simply the opinion of the Plant manager, and more importantly the LOA/ADA Specialist.

Regarding the Plant manager's review and study in preparation for the purchase of the new stand-up forklifts, the ONLY evidence provided by the Company was the manager's testimony. Not a single piece of documentation, outside of the briefing slides
Employer exhibit, E-1. and vendor provided manuals
Arbitrator/Joint exhibit, A/J-6. was offered into evidence to support the manager's testimony regarding his pre-purchase review, analysis, and investigation. There was no evidence provided that the Plant manager sought advice from anyone or any place outside of the Company and the vendor in his efforts to research available forklifts, their advantages/disadvantages, safety record, or anything else.

In its post-hearing brief the Company provided that it chose ‘“not to address the testimony of the Union's proffered forklift “expert,” as the witness' testimony confirmed he had not visited the facility, nor did he have any knowledge of the Company's operations…;’” and, dismissed that testimony as “immaterial” to the questions presented. However, it failed to offer any evidence that the Union witness's testimony regarding the “safety” of sit-down and stand-up forklifts in general was incorrect of should not be considered. That witness clearly testified that much of the information he provided the Union, including the judicial cases cited, was readily available on the internet. Yet, the company provided no similar evidence for its position. In an effort to determine if the witness was correct, the Arbitrator was able to identify and locate considerable information on the safety of forklifts in general,
Including the OSHA Safety and Health Bulletin SHIB 07-27-2009 on Standup Forklift Under-ride Hazards, offered into evidence by the Union (part of U-1); as well as more specific information relating to the safety of stand-up forklifts [e.g. a report issued by the National Academy of Forensic Engineers in June 2008 titled Forensic Engineering Assessment of Safety for Stand Up Forklifts by Richard M. Ziernicki and Ben T. Rallsback.] as well as, guidance on deciding between sit-down and stand-up forklifts
For example, Kelby Ergo Design a full service workplace process improvement, efficiency and ergonomics consulting firm based in the Twin Cities metro area of Minneapolis, Minnesota, in 2014 put out a document providing considerations for deciding between sit-down and stand-up forklifts suggesting things to consider for in each, such as that…Sit-down Forklift Physical Demands: low energy expenditure, neck rotation and extension, trunk twisting (driving in reverse), and whole body vibration transmitted through pelvis to the spine. Verses Traditional Stand-up Forklifts Physical Demands: higher energy expenditure due to more physically active work, whole body vibration absorbed by the legs, some stability provided by hip rest/pads, less trunk twisting, knee stress. And, Sit-down Forklift Safety Considerations: driver protected by vehicle frame (from falling objects) and seat belt, pedestrians can be run over by rear wheels if too close to moving forklift, blind spot located in rear quadrant when driving in reverse If driver doesn't/can't twist trunk and rotate head/neck for full view. Verses Traditional Standup Forklifts Safety Considerations: driver may or may not be protected by vehicle frame, foot crush injuries may occur when drivers extend foot out, mast elements may create blind sport. As well as other considerations., in one simple internet inquiry; which clearly showed, as the Union's witness testified, that there are advantages and disadvantages to both sit-down and stand-up forklifts; as well as between makers and models of each type lift.

The Union offered into evidence copies of the Company's OSHA Form 300, Log of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses for the years 2010 through 2014; and internal Company Supervisor Report of Occupational injury or Near Miss, for the years 2011 through 2014, it requested and received from the Company. The Company referred to the Union's exhibits both during the hearing and in post-hearing briefs but did not expand on or further explain that information. Cross examination of the Plant manager clearly showed he was not aware of the various judicial opinions offered into evidence by the Union; nor of the OSHA Safety and Health Bulletin issued on stand-up forklifts. Whether or not the particular cases cited by the Union specifically concerned the style lift purchased by Dart or resulted in findings against the Crown Equipment Company is not material. However, one would expect even a nominal research effort, particularly one that was supposed to have included looking at the OSHA website, as the Plant manager testified having done, would have found the safety and health bulletin. The point is, the Company failed to offer concrete evidence to support its manager's testimony.

As for the facilities past safety record – The Company, in its post-hearing rebuttal discounts and refutes the Union's assertions and argues that the evidence shows the safety results the Company experienced after the introduction of stand-up style forklifts reinforces that the switch has led to a safer workplace. However, the Arbitrator's review of Union exhibits five and six revealed none of the incidence reported on the OSHA Form 300s provided for the years 2010 through 2014 involved forklift operators or receiving truck operators. If any of these incidents involved the operation of a forklift, that forklift was apparently not operated by a forklift operator, but another employee (e.g., a packer, pressman, machine operator, etc.) using the forklift on an occasional basis. As for the eleven (11) Supervisor Reports of Occupational Injury or Near Misses provided for the period 2011 through 2014, seven (7) involved what was identified as PTO drivers (only three of which could be identified as forklift operators) having incidents between 2011 and 2013; and, two (2) involved PTO drivers (both identified as forklift operators) incidents in 2014. Accordingly, while the record does show that there were only two incidents that occurred since the Introduction of the stand-up lifts, one in April and one in June 2014 and both involved forklift operators; the Arbitrator finds the evidence does NOT clearly show marked improvement in safety between what occurred before the introduction of stand-up forklifts and after the introduction of stand-up forklifts, since the data only covered two months after the Introduction of the new forklifts.
With regard to the Company's denial of the Grievant's request that she be allowed to return to using a sit-down forklift — the first time because the LOA/ADA Specialist determined…

blockquote.p: “…it would impede the facility's ability to realize the important ergonomic and safety gains sought in the switch to stand-up forklifts;”

body.p: and the second time because the LOA/ADA Specialist determined…

blockquote.p: “Due to the safety and ergonomic concerns encountered with the sit-down type of fork-lifts safety-based decision was previously made to eliminate them from the plant by the end of the of 2014. There currently are 2-3 sit-down type of fork-lifts remaining in the distribution center which will also be eliminated by the end of the year for safety reasons. Despite the pending elimination of said fork-lifts deemed to be less safe, we still made inquiries of employees in those positions as to whether they might voluntarily exchange positions with you. We found no employees willing to make the exchange. Therefore, a sit-down type of fork-lift is not available.”

body.p: The Company argues that “the LOA/ADA Specialists' determinations were grounded in the following rationale: (1) potentially jeopardizing a facility's safety program by reversing safety-specific initiatives, particularly when said program is showing positive results, is inherently imprudent; and (2) future injuries on reintroduced sit-down forklifts could expose the Company to untold liability after publically broadcasting to its workers that said forklifts were a less safe equipment option.” Citing Jarvis v. Potter, 500 F.3d 113, 1124 (10th Cir. 2007) the Company argues the “LOA/ADA Specialists' reliance on speculative, yet foreseeable, harm was not an unreasonable approach, particularly since the law encourages proactive measures, and does not require [an employer] to wait for a serious injury before eliminating a direct threat.” Noting that “the Union and perhaps even the Arbitrator may disagree,” the Company goes on, citing EEOC v. Beverage Disfrib. Co. LLC, 780 F.3d 1018; U.S. App. LEXIS 4067, as well as Jarvis, to caution that “disagreement, from Grievant and Fact Finder alike, is legally immaterial in determining whether the Company's reasonable belief affords it an affirmative defense to claims of disability discrimination.”

Both cases cited by the Company involve the issue of “direct threat” Under the law a “direct threat” involves a significant risk of substantial harm to the health and safety of the person or others that cannot be eliminated or reduced by reasonable accommodation.”
29 C.F.R §1630.2(r). As explained by the Court in EEOC v. Beverage, and Jarvis, the existence of a direct threat is an affirmative defense to a statutory claim of discrimination. For this defense, the defendant (the Employer) has to show that it reasonably determined that the plaintiff (the party raising the discrimination claim) posed a direct threat. The fact-finder does not independently assess whether it believes that the employee posed a direct threat, but determines instead whether the employer's decision was objectively reasonable.

It is important to note, that the cases cited concern the “direct threat” of the employee or person, not a threat from a piece of equipment In its arguments, the Company has failed to make the distinction between: (1) whether it believes the Grievant posed or poses a direct threat herself; (2) whether the concern is that the sit-down forklift posed or poses a direct threat because management deemed it an unsafe piece of equipment; or (3) if the direct threat is posed by allowing the Grievant to again drive a sit-down lift. If the Company is asserting that the Grievant poses a direct threat, it has failed to provide any evidence or argument that this is the case. If the Company is asserting that the sit-down lift poses the direct threat, it is misapplying the “direct threat” defense. If it is asserting that allowing the Grievant to return to operating the sit-down lift poses the “direct threat” again it's misapplying the defense and cannot support such an assertion because the evidence shows that the Grievant drove a sit-down lift for some twenty-four years without any accidents or injuries.

In requesting to be allowed to use a sit-down forklift the Grievant and her medical providers believed the request to be reasonable since there were sit-down forklifts available; and, as the Union points out, the Courts and Arbitrators have held that employers, as part of the reasonable accommodation obligation must provide special and/or modified equipment to enable disabled workers to perform the essential functions of their jobs.

It is true that the Company did not have to provide the preferred accommodation requested by the Grievant, to be allowed to use a sit-down forklift; and, as it did in the Initial request, where more than one accommodation was suggested by the employee, can choose the accommodation it finds reasonable, so long as it is effective. Where the employee offers only one accommodation, in the interactive process envisioned by the ADA, it is anticipated that the employer will offer alternative suggestions and discuss their effectiveness with the employee. In the subject case, however, the evidence suggests the “interactive process” followed by Dart was mostly one-sided, the Company waiting for the Grievant and/or her medical providers to suggest the accommodation and the Company reacting to that request When at the end the Grievant and her medical providers could only recommend one accommodation, allowing the Grievant to use a sit-down lift, the Company made no further accommodation suggestions it simply separated the Grievant. While it claimed it looked for other positions that the Grievant was qualified for and no openings were available, or were projected to be available; it could have “thought-outside-the-box” and been a little proactive by suggesting changing the Grievant's work schedule from a twelve hour schedule to an eight hour schedule; and, while it is not required to create a new position it could have restructured the Grievant's position; or, while no employees volunteered to exchange positions with the Grievant, the Company could have exercised its management right as provided in Article 5 and transferred the Grievant and one of the warehouse receiving power truck operators to and from each other's position.
The Arbitrator notes that bath the Company and Union addressed management's questioning of the forklift drivers in the warehouse to see if they would be willing to swap positions with a forklift operator in the production area. The Company argues that “Asking the warehouse forklift drivers to consider swapping position was a function of the ADA interactive process, directed by the LOA/ADA Specialist in order to fulfil the Company's legal obligations under the federal law, an issue beyond the scope of the CBA. It was not intended, and in fact did not encroach upon the Union's right as the exclusive bargaining agent on matters contained in the CBA. The Union submits that the Company was legally required to bargain over these matters with it and not go directly to the employees; and provided a National Labor Relations Board opinion addressing a similar situation Paul Mueller Company, 332 NLRB 332 (2000). Since this issue was not included in the subject Grievance and the Union did not asked the Arbitrator to consider the matter, the Arbitrator will not address the matter.

While the Company did not have to show the Grievant that providing her requested accommodation would present an undue hardship to the Company, it needed to show the Arbitrator that providing the requested accommodation would require an undue hardship as defined and envisioned by the ADA – And, while the Company, in its post hearing brief provided that the LOA/ADA Specialist(s) determined that “reintroduction of a sit-down style forklift would be an undue hardship on the operations of the business under the ADA” – Simply put, the Company did not provide any evidence to the Arbitrator that the Grievant's reouested accommodation. to be allowed to use a sit-down forklift required significant difficulty or expense, or attempt to address the factors outlined in the ADA
Undue hardship is defined in the ADA as:
(A) In general — The term undue hardship means an action requiring significant difficulty or expense, when considered in light of the factors set forth in subparagraph (B).
(B) Factors to be considered in determining whether an accommodation would impose an undue hardship on a covered entity, factors to be considered include
(i) the nature and cost of the accommodation needed under this chapter;
(ii) the overall financial resources of the facility or facilities involved in the provision of the reasonable accommodation; the number of persons employed at such facility; the effect on expenses and resources, or the impact otherwise of such accommodation upon the operation of the facility;
(iii) the overall financial resources of the covered entity; the overall size of the business of a covered entity with respect to the number of its employees; the number, type, and location of its facilities; and
(iv) the type of operation or operations of the covered entity, including the composition, structure, and functions of the workforce of such entity; the geographic separateness, administrative, or fiscal relationship of the facility or facilities in question to the covered entity

As the Union points out, the Courts have ruled determining undue hardship “requires a fact-specific, individualized inquiry
Nunes v. Walmart Stores, 164 F.3d 1243, 1247 (9th Cir. 1999); based on concrete evidence;
Morton v. Untied Parcel Service, 272 F.3d 1249, 156-157 (9th Cir. 2001) and that assumptions or opinions are not sufficient to establish undue hardship.
Anderson v. General Dynamics, 589 F. 2d 397, 402 (9th Cir. 1979

While, the Company argues the Arbitrator should accept the LOA/ADA Specialist's determination because she relied on “speculative, yet foreseeable, harm;” the fact is the decision was based on pure speculation and nothing but speculation and personal opinion — The unsubstantiated, unsupported opinion of the Plant manager that the stand-up lifts were safer than the sit-down lifts, as well as, the equally unvalidated opinion of the LOA/ADA Specialists. Clearly, the LOA/ADA Specialists' decisions, particularly with regard to allowing the Grievant to use a sit-down forklift, were not based on objectively determined facts – Or at least the evidence does not point to any concrete factual evidence.

The Company failed to show by a preponderance of “factual and case specific” evidence that granting the Grievant's accommodation request to be allowed to use a sit-down forklift was unreasonable because it would require “significant difficulty,” not merely speculated problems based on unfound opinion; or expense, considering the nature and cost of the accommodation, the overall financial resources of the facility and Company, and other factors identified in the ADA.
42 U.S.C. §1211(10)(A)…factors to be considered Include —
the nature and cost of the accommodation needed under this chapter;
the overall financial resources of the facility or facilities involved in the provision of the reasonable accommodation; the number of persons employed at such facility; the effect on expenses and resources, or the impact otherwise of such accommodation upon the operation of the facility;
the overall financial resources of the covered entity; the overall size of the business of a covered entity with respect to the number of its employees; the number, type, and location of its facilities; and
the type of operation or operations of the covered entity, including the composition, structure, and functions of the workforce of such entity; the geographic separateness, administrative, or fiscal relationship of the facility or facilties in question to the covered entity. In fact, during direct examination when the Plant manager was questioned about the decision to purchase the new sit-down fork lifts he testified that cost was not an issue and said “how do you place a dollar value on the safety of your workforce.”
Per Arbitrator notes and audio file:
Company's Counsel:
So the decision [to purchase the new stand-up forklifts] was not reactive to one or more injuries Involved with fork trucks.
Plant manager.
No. I run a program and i've been in manufacturing nearly 25 years, and I always thought of myself as a proactive critical thinker. And I run a proactive program I don't; 1 think that you as a business leader you miss the boat if you're only ever reacting to incidents after they occur. The trick is to prevent the incidents from ever occurring in the first place. And that's kind of my thought process when I looked at these stand up lifts was seeing the ergonomics issues kind of on the rise in the facility that ultimately lead to injuries. What could we do to mitigate that risk and this was the big one.
Company's Counsel:
Was cost in any way part of the consideration at the time of the decision?
Plant manager
No. I mean, and here again how do you place a dollar value on the safety of your workforce. You've got the cost of the lifts. I will say that since Dart acquired Solo Cup I don't want to say that money is not an issue, but Dart is welt capitalized and I had no problems making the business case to make this kind of transition to stand ups. [Emphasis added]
Company's Counsel:
Were the standup lifts significantly less expensive than sit down lifts?
Plant manager:
They were basically the same price. They were right around $30,000 apiece. I don't recall exactly what that specific number is but like I said cost realty wasn't much of an Issue. Again you're buying a piece of equipment, you're no longer leasing it, so the thought process is when you buy it you own it, you're going to have to live with it, so do your homework, and that's what we did.
Company's Counsel:
Were the individualized circumstances or preference of any single employee considered during your decision making process?
Plant manager.
No, I make decisions collectively, for the good of the company, the good of the site. Since I came to Augusta that's what I've always, i have plant wide meetings pretty much every month and we talk about safety, quality, service, costs, and my commitment to keeping my 225 employees employed. And you do that by running a safe plant with the highest quality, with the best service, and you do it efficiently so that Its profitable for the company to keep us there. Because my job relies on that facility as well. So it was the right move for the site as a whole. [Emphasis added]
On this point the evidence shows the Company spent in the neighborhood of $210,000.00 purchasing seven new stand-up forklifts,
The Plant manager testified that the cost of the sit-down and stand-up lifts were about the same, $30,000 each, and he purchased two Yale standup forklifts, model ESC040ACN, and five Crown stand-up forklifts, model RC5530-30-180TT…At approximately $30,000 each that's $210,000.00. and relocated the “carton clamp” sit-down forklift from another Dart facility – But refused to spend $30,000 (about 15% of the cost of the seven new forklifts) for a sit-down lift for the Grievant to use; or to rent a new sit-down forklift, or even relocate a sit-down lift for the Grievant to use from one of Darts' other facilities.

Accordingly, the Arbitrator finds that the Company failed to provide the Grievant a reasonable accommodation and failed to show that providing the accommodation requested by the Grievant would pose an undue hardship.

Here the Arbitrator notes that the Grievant and Union has argued throughout this action that a sit-down forklift was available, in the facility, from the date of the Grievant's initial request through the date of the Grievant's separation AND the Company refused to provide one of the available sit-down forklifts to the Grievant as an accommodation for “reasons of safety.” Yet, the evidence shows in April 2014 when another fortdift operator complained that she was having issues with a lot of pain in her left knee and ankle, that the issues were preexisting, but it was “only since we went from the Yale sit down…fork lifts to the stand-up Crown forklifts that she has been unable to handle the pain. So she was directed to use the one Yale forklift left…to make it more accommodating for her.” While the record also shows that the forklift operator was informed this was not a permanent solution, she was directed to see HR in regard to the issue. Still, if the use of a sit-down lift on a temporary basis to accommodate this forklift operator who was having knee and ankle pain from operating the stand-up lift was allowed, it should have been allowed for the Grievant, even if on a temporary basis until some other reasonable accommodation could have been worked out.

Having found that the Company failed to provide the Grievant a reasonable accommodation; the Arbitrator finds the Company discriminated against the Grievant in violation of the ADA and Article 27 of the parties' CBA.
Accordingly, the Arbitrator finds that the Company did not have just cause to separate the Grievant from her employment.

The Arbitrator has strived to ensure both parties have had an opportunity to present sufficient evidence to support their case, through pre-hearing submissions, hearing testimony and offered evidence, and post-hearing briefs and rebuttals. Having considered all the evidence submitted, the following decision is rendered.
As to the issue before the Arbitrator…

p.b: Did the Company violate provisions of the parties' collective bargaining agreement and/or any provisions of Federal law when it separated the Grievant, Ms. Tamela R. Wells, from employment on October 10, 2014.

body.p: The answer is yes.

b.i: If so, what is the remedy?

p.b: As presented above, the Arbitrator finds the Union HAS shown by the preponderance of the evidence that the Company did not provide a reasonable accommodation for the Grievant and, therefore, discriminated against her. The Employer has NOT met its burden of proof and shown by the preponderance of evidence that it had just cause to separate the Grievant.

The Company, Dart Container Corporation, is ordered to fully reinstate the Grievant, Ms. Tamela Wells to her position as a forklift operator in the Solo Cup Operating facility in Augusta, Georgia with full seniority and all pay and benefits as previously received; and back pay from the date of separation to the date of this decision.
Upon Ms. Wells' reinstatement, the Company, Dart Container Corporation, is also ordered to provide the Grievant with a sit-down style forklift to use to perform her work as a forklift operator.

body.p: Finally, based on the request of the Union as presented in its post-hearing brief, the Arbitrator retains and reserves jurisdiction for a period not-to-exceed six-months to resolve any remaining issues regarding the implementation of this decision and award. This six-month time frame can be extended by request and agreement of both parties.

The FINDINGS, DECISION, AND AWARD OF THE ARBITRATOR as presented above are made pursuant to the provisions of Article 11 of the parties' collective bargaining agreement, and are final and binding on both parties.

In accordance with the provisions of Article 11, Section 2, of the CBA, the Arbitrator's fees and expenses will be billed to, and are to be paid in full by, the LOSING party, the Company, Dart Container Corporation.
Accordingly, Dart Container Corporation is directed to pay the total fees, compensation, and expenses of the undersigned Arbitrator as outlined above and presented by invoice under separate cover.
